We have a committee, which has been talked about in the speeches in this second reading debate, but it should be a matter for discussion whether, for example, we ought not have an independent review mechanism of the inspector-general’s role by eminent citizens. Jurists, for example, could have matters referred to them.
The very first sentence of the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice and Customs reads:

quote.para: The Intelligence Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 will assist in strengthening the contribution of sound intelligence to government decision making and operations.

speech.para: That is well and good, but in that rests the kernel of concern that I have. This is about strengthening the government’s decision making and operations. Senator Bartlett, who spoke before me, raised the concern that the intelligence agencies can become, more and more, operations for the government rather than for the country, for the nation—and that means rather than for the parliament. There is little reference indeed to the ability for parliamentary scrutiny outside of the designated committee.

I note that Senator Stott-Despoja’s proposal that there be a committee person who is not from the two big parties was given short shrift by Senator Ferguson in his contribution. He said that there are not enough members of parliament on the crossbenches or amongst the Independents in the House of Representatives to warrant that. That is a fault of the electoral system. There are certainly enough voters who support alternatives to the coalition or the Labor Party to warrant a representative of those voters being on this committee.

Senator Trood said—or used words to this effect—‘I think it would be quite inappropriate for us to give the committee the same powers as those in the United States and elsewhere.’ Really? I think that, in the absence of a bill of rights in this country and in the absence of a constitutional backup for the rights of citizens, we have an even greater need to be able to scrutinise the intelligence agencies to ensure that they are not cutting across the democratic civil, political, religious and other rights of individuals in our country. The need is even greater.

Since coming into this parliament, I have been consistently concerned that there is a cringe mentality about our intelligence services. I noticed in the contribution from Senator Ferguson we had the view that the committee has been taken into confidence by ASIO. Really? Are we as legislators, as the elected representatives in a democracy, as the absolute power base when it comes to supervising intelligence agencies, not able to inquire into every corner of those intelligence agencies? Of course we must be able to do that. That there are limits under legislation is a concern in itself. Senator Ferguson said that there have not been any leaks from that committee—nor should there be. The trust must be in the elected representatives of parliament to be able to investigate and to know about what is happening in every corner of the intelligence agencies, if our democracy is going to have a capital D and if the parliament is going to be the centre of the watchdog of the electorates and the rights of the people of Australia. We cannot leave that in any area to unelected, and therefore non-responsible, members of the intelligence community. They are there to defend the interests of this country and all of its citizens, but there is a worrying trend—the way the world is not working at the moment—in legislation coming through this parliament and our sister parliaments in similar democracies to hand more powers to people who are not elected against the interests of the electors of our countries.

I am grateful to Senator Milne for a copy of the front page of the United Kingdom’s Daily Telegraph of a week ago, Thursday, 29 September: ‘Heckler, 82, who dared to call Straw a liar is held under terrorist law’. Here we have at the Labour Party conference in Brighton an 82-year-old gentleman, Mr Wolfgang—who left Germany before mid-century to go to Britain—being arrested and issued with a section 44 stop and search form under the Terrorism Act because, in response to the asseveration of Britain’s minister for foreign affairs that Britain was in Iraq ‘for one reason only’, to help the elected Iraqi government, Mr Walter Wolfgang shouted, ‘That’s a lie and you know it.’ He was bundled out and arrested, as was somebody else, who said, ‘Leave that old gentleman alone.’ They were arrested in Britain.

What about Australia? An American citizen came to this country a few weeks ago to talk about peace. He is an activist for peace—very much in the tradition of Martin Luther King and Gandhi. He was summarily arrested and deported for reasons that we were told would not be made public. Then the part of the ASIO assessment that was thought to be inimical to Mr Parkin’s case—that he was a peace activist—was leaked on the front page of the Australian newspaper. Anyone who looked carefully at that leak could see that the claims against Mr Parkin were not that he had said anything that was untoward and certainly not that he had done anything that was other than peaceful; it was alleged that he was going to say that people ought to think about putting marbles under police horses at protests or to get people out of an arrest situation. Mr Parkin was going to say in fact nothing of the sort.

Mr Parkin has made it very clear that he hates cruelty to animals and is not in favour of attacking the police going about their duties as required under the laws of a country. But he was given no opportunity to put his case in our country. He was deported from this country on fabricated gossip or deliberate misinformation. Who made the decision to deport him? The Prime Minister of this country did—or at least he endorsed it. It would not have happened without that endorsement and it would not have happened without there being extensive communications between Canberra and Washington. No US citizen would have been deported from this country without the say-so of Washington—that is, the Bush administration.

What needs to be looked at there is that Mr Parkin is a very well-informed and intelligent critic of the Bush administration—not least the Vice President of the United States, Dick Cheney. Why? Amongst other things, Mr Cheney is the former CEO of Halliburton—a mega armaments manufacturer that is making billions of dollars out of armaments and, amongst other things, the invasion and occupation of Iraq. Mr Parkin was a thorn in the side of the Bush-Cheney administration. That is why the Howard government had him arrested and deported. I would be interested to know whether any government member, including the Minister for Defence, who is sitting opposite, can come forward in this parliamentary debate with a cogent other explanation for what happened. What I do know is that the leaking of the trumped-up charges against Mr Parkin which appeared in the newspapers was itself against the law in this country. I stand for the newspaper’s right to print information given to it, but that is very different to the leaking of information for political purposes against a political opponent.

Mr Ben Oquist, who formerly worked for me and now works for Ian Cohen, the Greens member of the upper house in New South Wales, wrote to the inspector-general after these events, calling for an inquiry. He received a letter back yesterday from the inspector-general, as I did, saying that he had referred the matter of that leak to the Australian Federal Police. It is a very serious matter, and one would expect that the Federal Police will have total access to both the Attorney-General’s Department and the Prime Minister’s office and staff to find out exactly who had that information. It is a very serious matter indeed when trumped-up information like that appears in the public arena and it is most likely it came from the office of the chief law maker in this country, the Attorney-General. It is very serious and dangerous, and no stone should be left unturned in bringing to book the people responsible for a process that can only be seen as similar to what happens when trumped-up charges are used to vilify people who stand for democracy and liberty in police states.

Draconian laws are being brought in to defend us from terrorism, and healthy debate takes place in democratic parliaments about the checks and balances involved there. The checks need to be very clear and very adequate, because the erosion of the rights which make our democracy and the liberties which Australians hold dear, and which indeed are incorporated in our Constitution, must not be allowed to proceed lightly. The role of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security is a very important one, but how well is it protecting us from political decisions—or the failure of political decisions—made on the basis of intelligence? Let me draw the Senate’s attention to the case of Chinese diplomat Chen Yonglin, who defected to this democracy of ours a couple of months back but who, in the process, had his whereabouts—or at least the fact that he had defected—implicitly handed across, against the law, to what is a police state: the Chinese government in Beijing.

I have no evidence—and certainly it has not come from the Minister for Foreign Affairs—that the minister did not discuss with the Chinese Ambassador on 2 June, just after Chen Yonglin’s defection, the matter of Chen Yonglin and what would happen to him when he went back to China. In the absence of a denial from Foreign Minister Downer, we must assume that that conversation took place. That is a breach of our nation’s laws, a very serious matter—because it was politically driven, if it happened, because this government did not want to be embarrassed by Mr Chen Yonglin’s defection when it is considering a free trade agreement with China. The ways of a police state are moving in on the ways of an open, free and safe democracy. There are questions there that have been left unanswered and which should be answered by the ministers responsible.

What of the matter of East Timor and that sterling member of our defence forces Lance Collins, who after a lot of travail brought forward what we now know to be the fact that intelligence was denied to the Australian defence forces for a period of time in East Timor because somebody in Canberra decided that it would not go forward? The inspector-general has found that that charge is in fact true. But who was responsible for making that decision in Canberra that our forces in the field would be denied intelligence? If serious charges like that are made, then those responsible for either breaking the law or endangering Australians looking after the interests of this country should be brought to book. But no, they are defended by a secret process and, I must say, by too many parliamentarians who feel it is not our responsibility to go looking into intelligence services. For some reason or other, many parliamentarians feel that this process could not be trusted. It is the essence of a democracy. We have to have the maturity and the responsibility to be able to acquaint ourselves with what is happening in the intelligence services and know that that is information that we have to keep to ourselves. This committee, as Senator Ferguson said, has done that well. There have not been leaks.

I maintain that we have an increasingly political use of intelligence—and I have not got onto the matter of SIEVX, another case where intelligence that we should know about has not been brought to public attention—under a mistaken concept. Intelligence is not the prerogative of government; it is the prerogative of the parliament acting on behalf of and in the best interests of the Australian people.

talk.start.para: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. The Intelligence Services Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 builds on the intelligence services legislation of 2001. It has resulted, firstly, from the advice given by Mr Philip Flood in his 2004 inquiry into Australian intelligence agencies and, secondly, from the government’s review of the operations of that 2001 legislation. Our knowledge has been benefited by the contribution also of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD, and we thank them for their contribution to this bill and also for the work that they have done in scrutiny of our intelligence agencies since 2001 under the existing legislation.

speech.para: The bill will enhance and strengthen the existing regime. At a time when good intelligence is possibly as important to Australia as it has ever been, it is an endorsement of the important role that these agencies have in our society. Also, it is an endorsement of the role of parliament in relation to providing an oversight of such organisations. The relationship and the responsibilities of the executive vis-a-vis the parliament in relation to intelligence agencies is not one of absolutes. In some ways this bill reflects a shared responsibility. The government still has the responsibility of governance but the parliament has assumed a right—and we respect that right—to provide a scrutiny of the agencies as well. And that is enhanced and strengthened in this legislation. Beyond the parliament, of course, we have other levels of scrutiny, such as the inspector-general, who is also to be commended for his oversight of the work of these agencies and for the element of public confidence that that adds to this debate. I thank honourable senators for their support for the legislation and I look forward to the committee stage.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to government amendments to be moved to this bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 5 October 2005.

—I ask the minister: could he outline to the committee the wherewithal of the office of the inspector-general? How many staff are there? What is the allocation? How has the government assessed that the increased responsibilities of the inspector-general which are inherent in this legislation are going to be carried out without an increase in the wherewithal of the office?

—I do not know the budget or the staffing levels of the office of the inspector-general, but I do know the inspector-general and, if he felt that he was unable to meet his responsibilities effectively because of a budget issue, I have full confidence that he would raise that with government. Certainly, in my experiences of the office—which includes a number of individuals who have held that office and their accounting to the Senate’s legislation committee in estimates—it seems to me that the inspector-general has been able to fulfil effectively the references that have been referred to him. This certainly gives him increased capability in terms of initiating his own references, but I have no reason to believe that there is any reason of budget or staff that would see him being unable to meet that responsibility.

—If the minister does not know what the budget is, could he find out and inform the committee? Could he also find out about the staffing levels and the staff make-up of the inspector-general’s office?

—I have been advised that he has six staff. I also know that he is supported by others when necessary. Senator Brown made reference to one IGIS inquiry in relation to Mr Collins. I certainly know that other agencies supported the inspector-general in his work on that inquiry. That was a difficult and complex inquiry, and he certainly was able to meet his responsibilities very effectively. So, if that is of any assistance to Senator Brown, I think that illustrates one example where the resources certainly seemed to be adequate for the task.

—On the face of it, when you extend the overview of the inspector-general’s office from three to six agencies, in particular the agencies operating outside of the country, then there should be an increased capacity in the office. It is logical that that should happen. I ask the government to look at that. The minister referred to the Collins outcome whereby the inspector-general did find that intelligence had been denied to the peacekeeping force, the Australians in the field, in East Timor. It is very germane to this. There is not much point in having an inspector-general’s office if findings like that are made and there is no consequent action. I ask the minister: could he tell the committee who was responsible for denying our forces in East Timor the intelligence that they should have had, albeit for a small but critical period of time? What action has been taken not just to ensure that that does not happen again but to ensure that the person or persons responsible have been properly dealt with?

—I refer Senator Brown to the report of Mr Carnell, which was publicly released. The report was an abridged version in terms of removing matters which were of security consequence or which were in breach of privacy principles. But it quite clearly set out the circumstances of that loss of access, and it made clear that it was a decision taken and made by certain officials. It was not in that report, but in my covering statements I advised the public that action had been taken against the individuals under the Public Service Act, and the matter had been thus completed.

—I do not agree with the minister that the matter has been completed. We have an Australian soldier, an officer, who stood up not just for his country but against an injustice done in an area where it was very difficult to pinpoint who had done it and why it had happened. I ask the minister: has Lance Collins been given the information about how it happened? And what remediation has there been? The minister says that the officials who acted wrongly in terms of that intelligence shutdown on the defence forces in East Timor have been dealt with. I think we ought to have a much clearer explanation of the way in which that dealing-with has been carried out.

speech.para: On the other side of the coin, what has the government done to make up for the travail of Lance Collins? Here is a brave and intelligent Australian who went through a lot of pain—one can only imagine it—to insist that a wrong be righted, despite the fact that he was rejected and, as is so often the case with people who make a stand like this, not thought the better of in some quarters. But he was shown to be right. In particular, one has to laud the courage and persistence he showed.

I ask the minister: understanding what Lance Collins has been through, what has the government done to ensure that restitution has been made for his contribution to making sure things are right and effectively his contribution to the safety of Australians in the field, in order to see that this does not happen again—that intelligence is not denied to people who are in the field in the service of this country? What has the government done, if not to reward Mr Collins then at least to make up for all he had to go through to get justice, and not for himself but for the defence forces he has so strongly stood up for? What has the government done there?

talk.start.para: —There are several questions from Senator Brown. In relation to the first, I repeat that disciplinary action was taken under the Public Service Act against those who took and implemented the decision to cut off that particular intelligence channel. As Senator Brown would learn if he read the report of Mr Carnell, the intelligence was nevertheless not seen as relevant to the tactical decisions that the force required in East Timor. There were other avenues of intelligence being provided to meet that responsibility. Nevertheless, the circumstances in which the full story was not disclosed to the previous inspector-general, Mr Blick, were particularly disturbing. That is what led to the disciplinary action being taken.

speech.para: Can I assure the Senate that there will be no further misdemeanours by any public officials? I cannot give that assurance, but I think it is highly unlikely. Our intelligence agencies are very professional. They comprise men and women who are committed to public service. They do a good job for our community. But they know as individuals that, if they make mistakes, there will be consequences associated with those mistakes, and that is what has occurred on this occasion.

talk.start.para: —I come back again to the case of officer Lance Collins. We have to take on the minister’s say-so what he says about the unnamed people in the intelligence services who cut off the intelligence. The minister says that on this occasion it fortunately did not make a difference to outcomes in East Timor. One can only imagine circumstances—and they were not in the hands of those who made the wrong decision here—where it would have made a big difference.

speech.para: Lance Collins had to persist against an earlier finding that the minister has referred to that he did not have a case. Because he was an honourable man and was determined that the truth would not be swept aside, he did persist and he was vindicated. But you do not go through years of fighting against an array of people who effectively say that you are not telling the truth or you are making something up, and you do not persist against an inquiry by an inspector-general which finds that you do not have a case, to the point where there is a reopening of the inquiry and you are found to be right, without very great personal sacrifice being involved. I ask the minister: what has the government done to make up for the personal sacrifices of this honourable and sterling Australian? Is the government not motivated to understand that a man or a woman who makes a stand like that must be not just vindicated but also rewarded to make up for all they have been through? That is very important. What has been done to ensure that officer Collins has had recompense for the honourable stand he took?

talk.start.para: —I do not know what sort of recompense Senator Brown is talking about. Certainly officer Collins, as has been referred to, persisted in his belief that the intelligence had been deliberately switched off, and the subsequent inquiry of Mr Carnell found that that was the case. That is not to criticise the previous inquiry. Mr Blick relied on certain statutory declarations and did not believe that he needed to go beyond them. I must say that I do not think that was an unreasonable position to take. But, when the matter was further pursued and the subsequent official, Mr Carnell, did go beyond the statutory declarations and, with the help of Defence, was able to reconstruct the computer records, it was established that this intelligence stream had for a short time been deliberately cut off.

speech.para: As I said, particularly in relation to the fact that certain officials had not been fully forthcoming in relation to that information—not so much in relation to the decision to terminate that particular intelligence stream, which is a different issue, but in dealing with the inquiry of Mr Blick—disciplinary action was taken under the Public Service Act. Mr Collins certainly was vindicated in that his belief that this intelligence stream was deliberately cut off turned out to be the case. If he had not persisted in that belief, it is true that we may never have found out the truth—we would have simply relied on the statutory declarations that certain officials had given earlier.

talk.start.para: —I make a suggestion to the minister through the chair: monetary considerations, recompense, is a matter that the government ought to look at. I am speaking of what I know from the public record, but it would seem to me that there must have been costs involved which ought to be looked at. However, much more important than that—because we are dealing with, again, an honourable person who went through a terrible ordeal—is to insist not just that the truth come out but that Australian service people in the field not be again put in the situation where intelligence operations are cut off for some reason—and there is not a good reason—back here in Canberra. I suggest that the Prime Minister call in officer Collins, shake his hand and thank him for standing up for our country and for the truth. I think the symbolism of that would go a long way towards making us all feel that when people follow through on their honest beliefs in the way he did they will be rewarded.

speech.para: I want to also ask the minister about the matter of Mr Scott Parkin. Can he give an explanation to the committee for the arrest and deportation of Mr Parkin, other than that which was released to the Australian newspaper last week?

talk.start.para: —I am not sure about what was released to the Australian newspaper. I do not have a brief on the circumstance in which his visa was cancelled. I understand that it related to security concerns. I therefore presume that advice was given by agencies which caused immigration authorities to withdraw the visa and his right to be in Australia in the interests of Australian security. If Senator Brown wants more than that, I will refer it to the immigration minister, but I suspect the response might be that it is inappropriate to put more than that on the public record.

—That raises the question of how appropriate it is for somebody in the government to release the information about Mr Parkin that was printed in the Australian. How appropriate is it for selected information—which is on the face of it wrong, vilifying and misrepresentative information—to be given into the public arena by the government? It did not come out of thin air. As I said in the second reading debate, I believe it came from the Attorney-General’s office. Unless we get evidence otherwise—and I should tell the committee that I will be moving for an inquiry by a Senate committee into this affair; and I will put forward a motion on that later in the day—I believe the government does need to give the people of Australia a better explanation of what happened.

speech.para: Everywhere I have been in the last couple of weeks, people have asked me how, in our democracy, this advocate of peace could be arrested and deported, on nothing more than what we saw leaked from the ASIO assessment—which was inimical to Mr Parkin, which he has denied absolutely, and which is patently false. There may be some other reason there. But if Australians are going to be assured that people in this country who advocate peace, but who might upset either this government or the US government in the process, are not going to be arrested in their beds, the government has got to be more open with the public than this. One thing we do know is this: whatever Mr Scott Parkin may have been alleged to be doing which may have been a threat to the security of this country, publicising it was not going to, of itself, threaten the country.

In the United States there would be a much more open parliamentary process than this. In the United States it is the congress that determines the President’s declaration of war. We do not have that in this country. It is not in our Constitution.

talk.start.para: —Senator Stott Despoja does have a private member’s bill on this. I will be supporting that bill, because it is fundamental that, in a democracy, the representatives of the people, not a minority of them in another place—and that means the Prime Minister’s office—declare war and send our Australian fellow citizens into a theatre of war. The parliament should deal with that matter, as is done in the United States.

speech.para: We do not have a bill of rights. We are, I think, one of only about two countries—of similar democracies—that do not have a bill of rights. So it is all the more important that, when it appears that a terrible wrong has been done, we do get from government a clear explanation. And this is the place to do it.

As to the arrest and deportation of Scott Parkin, not only is it a terrible wrong but he has got legal costs, and he was flown out of this country ignominiously with a security officer on either side and then sent a bill for that. What a travesty. There are echoes in this of burning witches at the stake. There are certainly echoes of the McCarthy period in the United States. And we must not allow wrongdoing like that—not by Mr Parkin but by those who decided he should be arrested, and that is the Attorney-General, the chief law officer of this country—to go unquestioned. It is not only our right, it is our responsibility to have questions answered on that.

I ask the Minister for Defence, representing the Attorney-General, to give this committee an explanation as to why Mr Parkin was deported from this country. Secondly, I ask him to give an explanation of how that leak of trumped-up information about Mr Parkin went into the public arena—‘from ASIO’, for goodness sake! I do not believe it came from ASIO. I believe it came from the briefing process where ASIO gave the information to the government and the government leaked it. That is very, very dangerous. That has to be questioned and pursued. Who is next if we do not pursue it?

I ask the minister to explain to this committee, here and now, what warranted Mr Parkin being summarily arrested and, without any trial in our country, deported. Yes, he had his visa removed. I ask the minister to explain that to this committee, or explain what is to be done to rectify the travesty, the injustice to Mr Parkin and to the Australian people, in front of our 20 million pairs of eyes, when he made a political decision—not a security decision; it ultimately had to be a political decision by the ministers involved—to have him arrested and deported. Please explain that.

talk.start.para: —I do not represent the Attorney-General, but I do respect the Attorney-General and I know that he would not be politically motivated in making such a decision. He would be acting upon advice, and that advice is given by officials who certainly have no political interest or bias but who give that advice on the basis of their professional knowledge and experience. A visa is not a right—it is a privilege, and if there is security advice that is inconsistent with that visa then action might flow from it.

speech.para: In relation to the leak of information, which Senator Brown alleges is from a security agency, that is a very serious allegation. Senator Brown has said that the inspector-general has referred the issue to the police for investigation, and I would respectfully suggest that Senator Brown should await the results of that investigation.

talk.start.para: —I ask the minister: could he outline to the committee, in our open, democratic chamber, what communications the government had with the Bush administration and its agencies about Mr Parkin before he was deported?

—I know of no communications with the United States. Although now is not really the appropriate time, if Senator Brown is asking that that matter be referred to the Attorney-General, it can be referred to the Attorney-General.
—Yes, I do ask the minister to ask that question of the Attorney-General and to report back to the committee or to the Senate.
—Has the government moved the amendments yet?
—I was waiting for an appropriate time. By leave—I move government amendments (1) and (2), as circulated:

amendment.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 64, page 14 (line 19), omit “Government”.
(2) Schedule 1, page 14 (after line 28), after item 64, insert:
64A Subclause 17(5) of Schedule 1
Repeal the subclause, substitute:
(a) the Chair is not present at a meeting of the Committee; and
(b) either:
(i) the meeting is one at which a question is to be decided by voting, or could reasonably be expected to be so decided; or

(ii) throughout a continuous period of more than one month immediately preceding the day of the meeting, the Chair was absent from duty or from Australia, or was for any reason unable to perform the duties of his or her office as Chair;

speech.para: the members present are to appoint a Government member to preside.

amendment.para: (5A) If:
(a) the Chair is not present at a meeting of the Committee; and
(b) the members are not required by subclause (5) to appoint a Government member to preside;

speech.para: then:

amendment.para: (c) if the Deputy Chair is present at the meeting—the Deputy Chair is to preside; or
(d) if the Deputy Chair is not present at the meeting—the members present are to appoint a member to preside.

(5B) A member who presides at a meeting of the Committee under subclause (5) or (5A) may exercise, in relation to the meeting and any matter arising out of the meeting, any of the powers of the Chair.

talk.start.para: —Just before we get into the detail of the amendments, I ask if the minister could give an affirmative answer to the chamber on the question I asked about referring the matter of Scott Parkin to the Attorney-General and getting a response for the committee or the Senate; will he do that?

—I am happy to refer the questions asked in this committee debate by Senator Brown to the Attorney-General and see if he wishes to respond. I think, if he does, an appropriate time for me to respond would be after question time when I have such a response. So it is a little out of order but, always wanting to be cooperative and helpful, I will see whether the Attorney-General wishes to provide information to the Senate on this matter.
—I refer the government to its amendments just circulated. I note in the bill’s EM just tabled that in the last sentence, in paragraph 1 under the heading ‘Outline’, it says:

quote.para: The Bill will be amended to reflect the substance of this recommendation.

speech.para: This refers to recommendation 1 of the review of the bill by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD. The recommendation was to use these words:

quote.para: If the Chair is not present at a deliberative meeting of the Committee—

speech.para: that is the first point—

quote.para: or is absent for a prolonged period …

speech.para: That is the second point. I want you to address both those points. I ask the government for some guidance as to why the amendment before the chair refers to, firstly, a meeting at which a vote is taken and, secondly, substitutes ‘one month’ for ‘absent for a prolonged period’. What is the reasoning behind the use of those words, as opposed to adopting the words that were in the committee’s recommendation? My understanding was that, firstly, it was a unanimous recommendation by both government and opposition members and, secondly, the words were worked out in the negotiation process. The government has chosen to accept in substance the recommendation but has a different form of words, and I was wondering if an explanation could be provided to the committee as to the meaning of the words that I identified in the amendment.

talk.start.para: —I should say for the benefit of Senator Mark Bishop that, as I understand it, these government amendments have been agreed with Labor members of the committee and came out of discussions subsequent to the joint committee’s recommendations. My recollection is that the original bill provided for the deputy chairman to be a member of the government. It was suggested to the government that that was not in the bipartisan spirit in which this committee operates—and it has operated very effectively in that regard.

speech.para: As the debate developed, it was then pointed out that on occasions of deliberative meetings leading to votes, and those sorts of situations, it might even be awkward for the opposition to find itself in the deputy chair position and it might well be more appropriate that it be a member of government. Therefore, this compromise set of words was devised which will allow a member of the opposition to be deputy chairman of the committee. But, for a deliberative meeting or where the chair has been away for a significant period of time, a member of government could take that chairing responsibility. I am not sure I am answering the questions that were asked, but I hope this background is useful. I will leave it at that, I think.

talk.start.para: —Just briefly, the Democrats support these amendments. You would have heard in my comments in the second reading debate the opposition we had to the notion that the deputy chair be a member of the government—something that I think is unprecedented in relation to a committee of this type but also because the committee structure and its work has relied upon, as Senator Hill pointed out, that bipartisan, happy nature. I get to the point of the spirit of bipartisanship, because I much prefer cross-party committees—and I mean ‘cross’ in a very happy way—that is, allowing for the multiparty democracy that is represented and reflected in this chamber. I think, if we are talking about a significant and appropriate expansion of the mandate and membership of the committee, then those changes should incorporate a member or members of the crossbenches in this place so that we are able to appropriately fulfil our job as legislators, particularly when it comes to matters of national security and/or importance.

speech.para: I am not suggesting that all members and senators obtain classified or national security briefings on occasions—far from it. You would have heard a number of times in the chamber that I have well and truly recognised that we do not always need briefings, nor should we be allowed access to briefings on operational and other security matters. However, I think an important step in the right direction would be to incorporate a crossbench member into this new joint committee. That is a position that the Democrats have held for a long time. I hope the government will consider that. Obviously, that is not going to happen today, but this amendment is certainly a good step as I think it was pretty appalling for the government to scoop up the leadership positions, for lack of a better phrase, on the committee—that is, the positions of deputy chair and chair of the committee.

As for Senator Bishop’s point on leaving out in one case the use of the word ‘deliberative’, I hear Senator Hill’s comments. I do not want to misrepresent you, Minister, but you did suggest that the opposition might be ‘uncomfortable’ in chairing a committee or a meeting of that kind. I think that was your terminology. Just quietly, I am not sure if the opposition would feel that uncomfortable, so I am a bit surprised that Senator Bishop on behalf of his colleagues is not pushing that change of wording a little further. This is certainly a start, because the other proposal was completely outrageous.

Again, I put on record that this committee is a bipartisan committee. That may sound nice and happy, but it is not good enough. It is not good enough when we are talking about important and serious issues to do with this nation’s security and our intelligence services. To exclude from that committee members of minor parties or even Independents and thus the crossbench, is outrageous particularly at a time when Australians are calling for greater accountability and greater scrutiny. If the government is committed to ensuring that there are safeguards and protections in place, particularly with the raft of legislation that it is about to introduce in the name of countering terrorism, then it will include multiparty representation on this committee, otherwise I have no doubt that Australians will continue to be somewhat sceptical about these oversight mechanisms in committees as they currently exist.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to unnecessarily prolong discussion on this point, but I should respond to the point raised by Senator Stott Despoja. She was raising a query about a question I asked of the minister. I note for the record that I asked the minister a question as to the reasons for the change in wording in the two paragraphs from the recommendation of the joint committee. As I recall, the minister responded that the detail of the amendment had been through discussions with opposition members of the committee. I have no reason at all to doubt the veracity of that response, and that is an acceptable explanation in answer to my query.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—On behalf of the opposition, I move opposition amendments (1) to (7) on sheet 4696 standing in my name:

amendment.para: (1) Schedule 1, page 5 (after line 21), after item 15, insert:
15A Section 3
Insert:
security has the same meaning as in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979.
(2) Schedule 1, page 7 (after line 21), after item 23, insert:
23A At the end of section 9
Add:

(6) The responsible Minister must notify the Attorney-General within 24 hours of giving an authorisation under this section for an activity, or series of activities, of a kind mentioned in subparagraph 8(1)(a)(i) or (ii).
(7) The responsible Minister must notify the Attorney-General in writing and must specify the facts and other grounds on which the responsible Minister gave the authorisation.
(3) Schedule 1, page 8 (after line 6), after item 24, insert:
24A After section 9
Insert:

speech.para: 9B Warrants

amendment.para: The relevant agency head of ASIS, DSD and DIGO must obtain a warrant from the Attorney-General under section 9C before:

(a) undertaking an activity, or a series of activities, for the specific purpose, or for purposes which include the specific purpose, of producing intelligence on an Australian person who is in Australia; or

(b) undertaking, in accordance with a direction under paragraph 6(1)(e), an activity, or a series of activities, that will, or is likely to, have an effect on an Australian person who is in Australia.
(4) Schedule 1, page 8 (after line 6), after item 24, insert:
24B After section 9
Insert:

speech.para: 9C Issue of warrants

amendment.para: (1) A request by the relevant agency head of ASIS, DSD and DIGO for the issue of a warrant in respect of activities in paragraphs 9B(a) and (b) must specify:
(a) the facts and other grounds on which the relevant agency head considers it necessary that the warrant should be issued; and
(b) the grounds on which the relevant agency head considers that the issue of the warrant advances Australia’s national security interests.
(2) Where, on receipt by the Attorney-General of a request by the relevant agency head for the issue of a warrant under subsection (1), the Attorney-General is satisfied that:
(a) any activities which may be done in reliance on the warrant will be necessary for the proper performance of a function of the agency concerned; and
(b) there are satisfactory arrangements in place to ensure that nothing will be done in reliance of the warrant beyond what is necessary for the proper performance of a function of the agency; and

(c) there are satisfactory arrangements in place to ensure that the nature and consequences of acts done in reliance on the warrant will be reasonable, having regard to the purposes for which they are carried out;

speech.para: the Attorney-General may, by warrant under his or her hand, subject to any conditions or restrictions that are specified in the warrant, authorise the relevant agency to undertake the activities of a kind mentioned in paragraphs 9B(a) and (b).

amendment.para: (3) Before the Attorney-General issues a warrant under this section for an activity, or a series of activities, of a kind mentioned in paragraph 9B(a) or (b), the Attorney-General must also:
(a) be satisfied that the Australian person mentioned in either of those paragraphs is, or is likely to be, involved in one or more of the following activities:
(i) activities that present a significant risk to a person’s safety; or
(ii) acting for, or on behalf of, a foreign power; or
(iii) activities that are, or are likely to be, a threat to security; or

(iv) activities related to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction or the movement of goods listed from time to time in the Defence and Strategic Goods List (within the meaning of regulation 13E of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations 1958); or
(v) committing a serious crime by moving money, goods or people; or
(vi) committing a serious crime by using or transferring intellectual property; or
(vii) committing a serious crime by transmitting data or signals by means of guided and/or unguided electromagnetic energy; or
(viii) an activity or activities that are, or are likely to be, a threat to security (whether or not covered by another subparagraph of this paragraph in addition to subparagraph (iii)).
(5) Schedule 1, page 8 (after line 6), after item 24, insert:
24C After section 9
Insert:

speech.para: 9D Content of warrants

amendment.para: (1) The Attorney-General may issue a warrant following a request in accordance with section 9C in relation to:
(a) an activity, or class of activities, specified in the warrant; or
(b) acts of a staff member or agent, or a class of staff members or agents, specified (whether by name or otherwise) in the warrant; or
(c) activities done for a particular purpose connected with the agency’s functions.
(2) A warrant is subject to any conditions specified in it.

(3) A warrant must be in writing and must specify how long it will have effect. The period of effect specified in a warrant for an activity or a series of activities, of a kind mentioned in subparagraph 8(1)(a)(i) or (ii), must not exceed 6 months.
(4) A warrant issued in accordance with section 9C may be revoked by the Attorney-General at any time before the end of the specified period of effect.

(5) If the Attorney-General issues a warrant under this section in relation to an agency, the relevant agency head must ensure that a copy of the warrant is kept by the agency and is available for inspection on request by the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.
(6) Schedule 1, page 8 (after line 6), after item 24, insert:
24D After section 9
Insert:

speech.para: 9E Issue of subsequent warrants not prevented

amendment.para: (1) Subsection 9D(3) does not prevent the issue of any subsequent warrant.
(2) Before a subsequent warrant can be issued, the relevant agency head must again comply with subsection 9C(1).
(7) Schedule 1, page 10 (after line 6), after item 36, insert:
36A At the end of section 15
Add:
(7) The retention of incidentally obtained intelligence concerning Australians that is not publicly available, must be minimised.

speech.para: I want to place a few remarks on the record with regard to these opposition amendments. As we acknowledged, this bill has been given fairly thorough scrutiny by the joint parliamentary committee, as we would expect, but we do note in passing that the government has chosen to ignore one of the committee’s recommendations on matters arising out of the bill. Accordingly, these amendments seek to implement the committee’s recommendations, particularly with regard to the issue of warrants—hence the amendments that have been circulated in my name.

The first amendment relates to the need to include within the act a definition of the word ‘security’. The opposition believes that the term ‘security’ should have the same meaning as in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979. In particular, the definition of security is most relevant in amendment 29 of the bill, which proposes to add a new subsection 11(2AA) in the following terms:

quote.para: After subsection 11(2)
Insert:

(2AA) An agency may communicate incidentally obtained intelligence to appropriate Commonwealth or State authorities or to authorities of other countries approved under paragraph 13(1)(c) if the intelligence relates to the involvement, or likely involvement, by a person in one or more of the following activities:
(a) activities that present a significant risk to a person’s safety;
(b) acting for, or on behalf of, a foreign power;
(c) activities that are a threat to security—

speech.para: ‘security’ being the keyword there—

quote.para: (d) activities related to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction or the movement of goods listed from time to time in the Defence and Strategic Goods List (within the meaning of regulation 13E of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations 1958);
(e) committing a serious crime.

speech.para: We believe that leaving that term undefined will potentially give the proposed subsection 11(2AA) unacceptably broad operation. Just as ‘foreign power’ has been defined in terms of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979, we think it is similarly appropriate to define the term ‘security’ in terms of that act. This gives the proposed subsection an operation that correlates to the use of equivalent powers by ASIO. Our argument is that it is appropriate in itself, and we note that our reasoning is entirely consistent with the unanimous view of the joint parliamentary committee.
For the benefit of senators interested in this debate, the definition of security in the ASIO Act is as follows:

quote.para: (a) the protection of, and of the people of, the Commonwealth and the several States and Territories from:
(i) espionage;
(ii) sabotage;
(iii) politically motivated violence;
(iv) promotion of communal violence;
(v) attacks on Australia’s defence system; or
(vi) acts of foreign interference;
whether directed from, or committed within, Australia or not; and
(b) the carrying out of Australia’s responsibilities to any foreign country in relation to a matter mentioned in any of the subparagraphs of paragraph (a).

speech.para: Incorporating that wording into the intelligence services bill is therefore appropriate.

The second set of amendments concerns the issue of warrants. Our view is that the committee’s views are relevant and ought to be put in the bill to put some limits on the government’s new powers. There was extensive discussion by the committee, and its deliberations are recorded at pages 11 and 12—paragraph 2.27 on page 11 through to para 2.36 at the bottom of page 12. It had been my intent to read those paragraphs into the record, but for the sake of time I would seek leave of the committee to incorporate paras 2.27 up to and including 2.36 on pages 11 and 12 of the parliamentary joint committee report. I seek leave to do that as opposed to reading out the entirety of those two pages.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

item.para: 27 The amendment in Schedule I Item 22, deletes the word “who is overseas” from the current legislation. As a result, ASIS, DIGO and DSD will be required to seek a ministerial authorisation to produce intelligence on an Australian person, whether that person is overseas or in Australia.

28 The ISA defines the functions of ASIS and DSD, and the bill legislates the functions of DIGO (as well as clarifying the roles of ASIS and DSD). For all three agencies, key functions include obtaining ‘intelligence about the capabilities, intentions or activities of people or organisations outside Australia’ (paragraphs 6(1)(a) and 7(a) and the proposed 6B(a)). In the case of ASIS, it is also tasked with undertaking ‘such other activities as the responsible Minister directs relating to the capabilities, intentions or activities of people or organisations outside Australia.’(paragraph 6(1)(e)).

29 In view of these apparent limitations on the agencies’ legal functions, it was not clear how the responsible Minister could authorise the agencies to undertake activities for the purpose of producing intelligence on Australians irrespective of whether they are inside or outside Australia. Similarly, in the case of ASIS, an issue arose as to ASIS’ power to undertake activities that may have a direct effect on Australians.

30 Schedule I Item 22 suggests that the ISA is already being interpreted to give ASIS and DSD the power to obtain intelligence on Australians inside Australia regarding the capabilities and intentions of persons outside Australia with the consequence that the amendments are needed to give Australians in Australia the same protections as Australians outside Australia.
31 It is relevant to draw attention to an answer given on 21 March 2002 by the Minister for Defence to a question on notice from Senator Chris Evans:

quote.para: To ensure that the privacy of Australians was properly protected irrespective of whether they were overseas or in Australia, my predecessor issued a direction to Director DSD under section 8(1)(b) directing DSD to obtain an authorisation before undertaking any such activities in relation to Australians within Australia. This direction took effect with the date of the introduction of the Act, and had the effect of requiring DSD to afford the same level of protection to all Australian persons regardless of their location.

item.para: 32 This answer indicates that at present, although protection of Australians inside Australia is not specifically legislated, there is in fact a ministerial direction under section 8(1) (b), which would enable the production of intelligence on Australians in Australia.

33 In the case of Australians outside Australia, the ISA provides that before any of the agencies can conduct an investigation, the Minister responsible must, pursuant to S8(1), require the agency to obtain Ministerial authorisation for the investigation.
34 Before issuing an authorisation the Minister must be satisfied that the Australian to be investigated is, or is likely to be, involved in one of the following categories:
activities that present a significant risk to a person’s safety;
acting for, or on behalf of, a foreign power;
activities that are a threat to security;
activities related to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction or the movement of goods listed from time to time in the Defence and Strategic Goods List; and
committing a serious crime.
35 The amendment is intended to have the effect of protecting Australians in Australia in the same way as the current legislation protects Australians who are overseas.

36 The Committee notes it is the case that the foreign intelligence gathering agencies can currently be authorised to obtain intelligence on Australians inside Australia regarding the capabilities and intentions of persons outside Australia. The Committee approves the proposed amendment at Item 22, but requests additional provisions, to ensure consistency in the requirements on all agencies, domestic or foreign intelligence gathering.

talk.start.para: —The opposition adopts the material contained in those paras as our reasons in support of the argument for all of the amendments relating to the warrants in amendments (2) through (7) before the chair. I note that the committee recommends that, as the regime moves from ministerial direction to legislated ministerial authority as proposed in item 22, it should generally replicate the provisions of and have identical authorisation provisions to those applied to ASIO.

speech.para: Finally, we put on the record that we also propose an additional amendment to minimise the prospect of misuse of incidentally obtained intelligence—that is the last amendment on the sheet in the name of the opposition before the chair. The reasons for this are self-explanatory and straightforward. We simply believe that information not relevant and incidental to any investigation should be disposed of.

talk.start.para: —I am sure that that was a very important speech and I would like to say that I heard every word of it—

—I would not want to blame your leader for interrupting my thought process. Instead, I will say that I will assume that Senator Bishop took up the position that is well known on this matter, reflected in his amendments, which is an alternative way of looking at the system of authorisations and approvals. These alternatives were discussed with members of the committee and they have been discussed with members of the opposition. I think I can fairly say that in the development of this bill to date there has been a cooperative approach. I respect the view of the Labor Party that the Attorney-General’s approvals should be required in relation to authorisations of the Defence intelligence agencies.

speech.para: Whilst I respect that view, the government does not agree with it. There are responsibilities that the Minister for Foreign Affairs has in relation to ASIS. There are responsibilities that the Attorney-General has in relation to ASIO. In relation to Defence Intelligence Organisation, Defence Signals Directorate and DIGO, the imagery organisation of Defence, the governance responsibilities are those of the Minister for Defence. The safeguard is that these intercepts cannot occur and foreign intelligence cannot be sought in the circumstance of Australian citizens without the authority of the minister, and this is made absolutely clear and unambiguous in the bill that is before the Senate.

There has been some criticism which I also respect of the 2001 legislation, which did not leave the matter as clear as some would like, even though by means of a directive the authority of the minister has been required for all such collections. But I do not see any room to argue that this bill could be criticised in the same terms. It makes it absolutely explicit that the authority of the Minister for Defence will be required before any such collection is undertaken. The bill sets out and the legislative background, the 2001 legislation, sets out the circumstances in which such collection is valid and the limited circumstances in which it can be progressed. If you add together the legislative restraints, the professionalism of the Public Service, the responsibility of the executive and the overall scrutiny of the Inspector-General, I think it is a very safe system.

talk.start.para: —I have heard the minister describe these amendments put forward by the opposition as an alternative. I do not think they are necessarily an alternative. What I see before us in these amendments are some quite clear specifications in the case of warrants for the issuing and the contents of warrants. I have heard the minister’s comments in response to the amendments and Senator Bishop’s query but I have not heard any specific reason or any specific concern about any of the contents in the amendments before us—that is, if we are using the word ‘safeguard’ or, to use the minister’s terminology, ‘protections’, there is no harm that I see. In fact, I think it is an improvement on the legislation for us to specify under what circumstances the issuing takes place and again to specify the content.

speech.para: If it is a completely different perspective—that is, the government does not want to add any more specifications—that is one thing, but what is wrong with the specifications before us? I have not heard any examples from the minister as to why the amendments before us—for example, amendment (4)—would inhibit in any way the responsibilities and the functions of the ministers to whom he referred. I see these as good steps forward in providing some protections and some safeguards. It is not perfect but it is certainly better. I am just wondering why the government is rejecting these amendments.

talk.start.para: —My argument is that the safeguards that are provided in the 2001 legislation and enhanced and clarified by these amendments are more than adequate to meet the task. What the opposition is doing, in my view, is adding another layer of safeguards but, in doing so, is blurring the responsibility in relation to defence agencies between that of the defence minister and the Attorney-General. Not only do I think that is confusing but also I think it is unnecessary. There are obligations in relation to warrants that are upon the Attorney-General; there are obligations in relation to authorisations that are upon the defence minister. In relation to their respective agencies, I believe that the systems have worked well and are, as I said, improved and clarified by the bill that is before the chamber at the moment. So, both in terms of adding a further and unnecessary layer of regulatory requirement and also in terms of blurring the responsibility between the two ministers, I would argue against the amendments the Labor Party is proposing.

—I am a bit surprised that the opposition do not want to take up this point and argue the point or at least defend their amendments. I actually think their amendments are reasonably good. I do not want to take the call in advance of anyone from the Labor Party but I have to pick up on the point of layers or constraints. Under these amendments in relation to 9C and the issuing of warrants, the third point states:

quote.para: Before the Attorney-General issues a warrant under this section for an activity, or a series of activities, of a kind mentioned in paragraph 9B(a) or (b), the Attorney-General must also:

speech.para: Then you have a series, which I do not see as a particular constraint. The amendment continues:

quote.para: (a) be satisfied that the Australian person mentioned in either of those paragraphs is, or is likely to be, involved in one or more of the following activities:

speech.para: Then there is a list—a smorgasbord:

quote.para: (i) activities that present a significant risk to a person’s safety; or
(ii) acting for, or on behalf of, a foreign power; or
(iii) activities that are, or are likely to be, a threat to security; or

speech.para: It goes on; it is ‘one or more of the following activities’. You have points like point (iii)—‘activities that are, or are likely to be, a threat to security’. I do not see that these are severely curtailing or constraining the abilities of the Attorney-General in this case. Even when it is read not only in conjunction with the current sections of the act—and let us face it: this updated bill does not really specify in too much more detail what can and cannot be done—but also in conjunction with the first two points in relation to the issuing of warrants under the Labor Party amendments, they are pretty reasonable positions. In fact, some people might argue they are not strong enough. I am just wondering what is wrong with putting in these clarifications in relation to the issuing of warrants. Is there a specific reason that the government can give us, apart from all this namby-pamby that it is duplicating or it is constraining or it is difficult for the ministers? What is difficult about having to satisfy one or more of these criteria before the warrant is issued?

talk.start.para: —There is nothing difficult about that. The issue is whether you need to satisfy one minister or satisfy two ministers. The safeguards that were read out by Senator Stott Despoja are in the existing legislation and they are an obligation upon the Minister for Defence. The Minister for Defence, before giving an authorisation, has to be satisfied that the person mentioned is involved in one or more of the following activities: activities that present a significant risk to a person’s safety; acting for, or on behalf of, a foreign power; activities that are likely to be a threat to security, et cetera. It is not that I am arguing that these are the limited circumstances in which an authorisation might be given; quite the contrary. I believe that that is an important safeguard upon the powers that are given in this legislation to the security agencies. I just do not see merit in the argument of requiring not only that the Minister for Defence satisfy himself of all these matters but also that it then be done by the Attorney-General as well.

speech.para: Question negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL COLLEGES (FLEXIBILITY IN ACHIEVING AUSTRALIA’S SKILLS NEEDS) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 4 October, on motion by Senator Coonan:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Technical Colleges (Flexibility in Achieving Australia’s Skills Needs) Bill 2005, in my view, is one of the more cynically named bills to come before this chamber in the last three years. We are told that this bill is all about addressing Australia’s existing skills shortage. It is one of the key policies that the Howard government took to the election last year. The thrust of this bill is that the creation of 24 Australian technical colleges, new colleges outside the existing vocational education system, will be one of the key components in addressing the current skills shortage in our economy. We are told that this federal government package will eventually deliver something like 7,000 places per year. Whilst I accept that there is a need for increased skills training and education in Australia, the federal government’s creation of a new system of technical education is not the magic bullet. In fact, it will not be the answer in the short term anyway.

speech.para: How long will we have to wait to see a student graduate from an Australian technical college with a trade qualification? Four years at the earliest, and that is based on the proposition that the colleges are up and operating now, and of course they are not—unless the government also seeks to downgrade and shorten trades training. The earliest that we can expect to see a graduate from an Australian technical college would be about 2010. It seems that we have a government that is a bit like a hamster on an exercise wheel: an awful lot of movement but going absolutely nowhere.

I have spoken many times before in this place about the absurdity of our current skills shortage. My point then, and again now, is that the skills shortages in Australia did not come out of nowhere. There are many leading indicators of impending skills shortages. These include factors such as the number of people commencing an apprenticeship, the number of people completing an apprenticeship, the number of people retiring from the work force by occupation, the number of skilled migrants entering the work force and the growth in trade job vacancies. This is just a small sample of those leading indicators.

The government, through its Public Service agencies, including those agencies concerned with immigration, employment, education and the Bureau of Statistics, has resources allocated to collecting all this data. Knowing the professionalism of the Public Service, I am sure that all of this data is available to the ministers concerned. The problem for Australia is that the ministers responsible have simply not been interested. Simply put, the skills shortages that now exist have been coming for years. The lead indicators have been telling us this and the government has failed to act.

Now that we have a skills crisis, the Howard government burst onto the scene with a range of new policies. What have the government delivered after nine long years with their dead-end skills policies? We end up with a toolbox for apprentices and Australian technical colleges. But wait, there is more! When all else fails, we will simply allow more skilled migrants to come here. There you have it: a crisis that they knew was coming that was addressed initially by increasing the number of skilled migrants and is now being addressed through the creation of new technical colleges.

Those opposite should be awarded points like in a diving competition for the degree of difficulty in managing this problem. Every time that this country is confronted with serious issues, those opposite come up with complicated and twisted applications of logic and commonsense to address the problems. Anyone who believes that the most effective and efficient use of taxpayers’ money to address the skills shortage is to duplicate elements of the existing technical education system is really all about wasting money, time and effort.

A technical and further education system already exists in this country. The system, which is administered by the states and receives funding from the Commonwealth, is responsible and has been responsible for skills training for years—even under Liberal governments. Instead, with a degree of difficulty and waste not seen for a long time, this government come up with the idea of starting from scratch. First, they have to go through the process of finding interested organisations to develop and run these technical colleges. Then they have to go through a tendering process. Then the minister gets to run around and hold lots of press conferences. The successful organisation then has to go and find suitable sites and then construct the buildings, I guess. Then, of course, they would have to engage staff, develop a curriculum, advertise for students, start the training, manage the business and then, finally, have a graduation ceremony.

After a period of at least four years and based on all the things that need to happen before the first intake, this policy would finally deliver the Howard government’s response to the skills crisis. Each year that the system is fully operational after that initial development, it will deliver at best 7,200 skilled workers into our economy. When considering this issue we must keep in mind that over the coming five years the estimated skills shortages in the Australian economy will run to some 130,000 places. This is on top of the existing shortages of approximately 20,000 skilled workers. The Australian people need to understand that simply creating a new technical college system will still leave a five-year shortfall of about 120,000 places—an incredible obstacle to our full economic development and growth. You do not address a skills crisis by duplicating existing systems and structures that will deliver only 7,000 places a year when fully operational.

As I said before, it seems to me that those opposite like to complicate things. For nine years they have essentially been reducing their funding of TAFE places. The net effect has been that around 270,000 fewer places are available. Compare that with the anticipated shortfall of 120,000 skilled workers and the existing shortfall of 20,000. It could have been more than adequately covered if funding had been maintained for the TAFE system. Now, when the government need to address their own neglect of Australia’s skilled worker requirements, rather than working cooperatively with the states and territories, they have to go and create their own technical colleges.

The 7,000 places a year that may eventuate from Australian technical colleges could have been delivered at a lower cost and in a more timely manner if the Commonwealth could have seen its way clear to work with the states. Let that be remembered when we discuss this legislation. The skills crisis is not only a policy failure—a failure by successive Liberal employment and education ministers to take heed of the lead indictors that pointed towards a looming skills shortage quite some time ago—but also a failure of the Commonwealth to work cooperatively with the states.

This is obviously of concern to some of the state Liberal members. One Friday night last month, on the Stateline program on the ABC in Perth, a former minister of the Court government was openly advocating a discussion about Western Australia seceding from the Commonwealth of Australia. I wonder if the Hon. Norman Moore MLC has adopted that position because of the level of concern he has with the behaviour of the Commonwealth government. Can anyone be surprised that members of the Liberal and National parties in state parliaments are increasingly concerned about the actions of the Commonwealth government?

The conservative parties in Australia have normally been opposed to the centralisation of power in Canberra. Now, they are witnessing a Liberal government that each day seems to come up with new ways to take more power into Canberra and away from the states. The Hon. Norman Moore echoed those concerns on that Friday night. In the area of technical education, the states and the Commonwealth should be working together to ensure that skills development in the Australian work force is delivered in the most cost and time effective manner possible.

During the last federal election campaign, the government were called to task over the skills crisis. Their solution was the provision of a tool box and the creation of the Australian technical colleges framework. Some 12 months down the track, we are only just now getting the legislation—talk about policy development on the run. If this is the Commonwealth’s considered response to the skills crisis, we should not have had to wait this amount of time. Surely the Commonwealth would have been prepared for action immediately after the election, not some 12 months later. Instead, we see the continued erosion of our Federation.

If this is really the sum total of the Commonwealth’s response to the skills crisis then it falls well short of the needs of the Australian economy. It falls short by some 120,000 places over the coming five years. It is beyond belief that the Commonwealth can only come up with 7,000 places in that five-year period for an expenditure of over $340 million. Much of the funding is going to capital expenditure, but how many more skilled workers could be funded if that money was allocated within the existing vocational education system? Surely, a much greater impact on the shortfall of 120,000 places could be made.

In conclusion, it is clear that the Commonwealth government have dropped the ball on this issue. For nine long years they did nothing except reduce the funding available to the public technical education sector. For nine long years they ignored the lead indicators that pointed to the looming skills shortage in our economy. When called to account during the federal election campaign last year, they came up with policy on the run—a policy to create 24 Australian technical colleges in a massive duplication of the existing technical education system, for purely political reasons. This policy will take at least four years—and maybe as many as five or six years, by the time we get there—to deliver a single skilled worker to the Australian economy. This is a government that are clearly not up to the task of managing Australia’s skills development.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats welcome the injection of additional funding for vocational education and training. However, we agree with the concerns of many who presented to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Legislation Committee inquiry into the provisions of the Australian Technical Colleges (Flexibility in Achieving Australia’s Skills Needs) Bill 2005 that using the funding to establish 24 Australian technical colleges does not optimise the use of that funding and sets up a system that could, in fact, have detrimental effects on other school based VET systems and the outcome for all students.

speech.para: Unfortunately, we are now faced with the extraordinary situation where it is not practicable to oppose or even amend the Australian technical colleges bill because, in the government’s arrogance, the majority of the 24 technical colleges proposed have been agreed to and are under way before the bill has even passed through parliament. I think this criticism is particularly valid, given that the decision to establish the technical colleges was a last-minute federal election promise that saw little, if any, consultation with state governments, schools, school principals, parent organisations or TAFE colleges. This is policy on the run, writ large.

The problem with implementing a policy before legislation has passed is very obvious. The parliament does not get the opportunity to properly scrutinise it and offer amendments which could improve outcomes for students, and those people who take the trouble to let us know their views, who often have much experience and expertise, are ignored. The government might argue that there is no need for scrutiny because there is support for the technical colleges and that that was demonstrated by the strong interest and the number of applications for tenders so far. However, interest in the colleges does not necessarily mean that the colleges will be in the best interests of students.

What I find most perplexing about the federal government’s decision is that stand-alone technical colleges used to be a feature of schooling in Australia. They certainly were when I was at secondary school. There were high schools and there were technical schools. Yet, after extensive reviews of education policy, it was judged to be a more efficient use of resources, a more equitable social approach and more educationally desirable to educate all students under a single comprehensive approach, and they were reintegrated into the mainstream.
The Australian Education Union, in their submission to the inquiry into the bill, outlined a number of reasons for the closure of stand-alone technical colleges—for example:

quote.para: • Many were resource intensive and to some extent, exclusive. There was little easy movement between academic and technical schools, with neither benefiting from the practices and resources of the other.
• Some technical schools became ‘ghetto’ repositories for working class kids and disengaged students from the high school stream.

• A mis-match occurred over the time between the skills the schools were established to provide, and the emerging skills in the economy. The schools therefore no longer met the demands of the industries they were meant to serve.

• It was acknowledged that all students needed some ‘vocational focus’ in their secondary education. This was especially so in the post-compulsory years (15-19) where with structural changes to the economy and the evolution into a postindustrial society, jobs were no longer available for 15 year olds or for those who were completing the senior school technical curriculum.
• It was also recognised that those students at technical college needed access to a broad general education which they were not able to receive within the limitations of a technical college.

speech.para: The Education Union warned that one of the long-term effects will be an emergence of the same issues that confronted technical colleges in the 1970s and 1980s, challenging social questions about streaming, from an entry level of schooling into a trade, students who were not considered bright enough to complete mainstream schooling. Yet it seems that the federal government is on track to make many of the same mistakes—and without too much input by anybody else.

The Democrats share the concerns of some of the submissions to the Senate inquiry that the language of the bill suggests that technical colleges will be industry led and there will not be an equal partnership between schools, industry and other stakeholders such as employers and representative organisations. Even the word ‘industry’ led to a misnomer, as they are more likely to be employer led. The Education Union in their submission made the observation that the technical colleges:

quote.para: ... are to be situated in regions with skills shortages and high youth unemployment, but where there is a significant industry base. The only conclusion is, that where these three conditions co-exist, local industry has to date taken no responsibility for training the next generation of skilled workers. Yet this very local industry is now to be charged with governing not merely some areas of training, but a school teaching academic subjects.
