speech.para: The Democrats share the AEU’s belief that ‘local industry does not have the expertise to carry out such a role’.

The union also raised concerns that the establishment of the technical colleges, coupled with superior funding, could weaken other school based VET initiatives. It has been estimated that, due to the additional funding, the technical colleges will operate at over 175 per cent of the average cost of educating a secondary student, which is a considerable financial advantage. We must remember that this is for quite a small number of students at that level—that is, year 11 and year 12. The union argued that, for want of comparative funding, many school based initiatives may not be able to compete with the offerings of the technical colleges and will have to reduce their programs accordingly.

In particular, schools may have to cut programs where student numbers would be too small to be viable, further limiting student opportunities. This will have a considerable impact on educational outcomes of students who do not attend the technical colleges but who will still wish to pursue a vocational pathway. It is also highly likely that, because the technical colleges will draw students away from existing schools and programs, this will result in alterations to funding of existing schools. The combined loss of students and funding is likely to affect the ability of the school to offer a maximum range of curriculum to all students. This would be particularly true for schools in regional areas which are already struggling for viability.

A number of submissions noted that principles such as equity have not been strongly expressed in the bill. The emphasis on traditional trades, which are mainly male-dominated trades such as metals and engineering, automotive, building and construction and electrotechnologies, will inevitably lead to failures to address gender participation or, more broadly, to offer courses that young women may be interested in pursuing. What happens if the aspirations, aptitudes or interests of a technical college student change? Will the technical college have the capability to offer the student alternatives? Will the technical college provide a level of education to enable students, should they wish, to undertake further education such as at university? I think it has to be remembered that many students enter year 11 with not a great deal of understanding or much idea about what they aspire to after school completion.

What concerns me the most about the government’s actions to date is that they have blindly and, I would argue, arrogantly pursued this flawed model for ideological reasons, including the pursuit of Australian workplace agreements, at the expense of alternative workable models. For example, the Queensland government, in their submission to the inquiry, argued that, while they support the policy intent behind the bill, they urge the government to consider alternative models that would achieve the same objectives and yet be more flexible as well as more consistent with current industry partnerships, especially in the regions.

The Queensland government have proposed a more flexible model, whereby students from feeder schools, both state and non-state, would maintain an enrolment in their respective schools and enrol in and attend the technical colleges to access high-quality, specialised trade training. The Queensland government argued that this dual arrangement would enable a greater number of feeder schools to participate and thereby deliver a broader range of options for a greater number of students. The Queensland government also argued that the dual model is particularly viable in regional areas, where the introduction of the colleges has the potential to create a competitor in what is a relatively small market. The Queensland government expressed concern that failure to accommodate other industry partnership models that are currently delivering significant outcomes for Queensland industry and students not only is regrettable but also could impact negatively on the cooperation that currently underpins successful industry and school partnerships.

It would be useful if the minister, in his contribution to the second reading debate, could indicate whether the federal government is prepared to consider more flexible models, as outlined by the Queensland government, and, if not, why this is the case. Several submitters to the inquiry on the bill rightly pointed out that the technical colleges will not produce a skilled tradesperson to come into the labour market until 2010 and that this will do nothing to assist the industries and the skills shortage now. The solution to skills shortages is not via a model of privatisation and competition for already scarce resources; rather, the solution lies in an integrated, collaborative model that supports existing schools and VET courses. We echo the sentiments of the Australian Education Union that technical colleges are, at best, a solution for a few at the expense of the many.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: (Senator Marshall)—Order! It being 12.45 pm, I call on matters of public interest.

talker.name: Boswell, Sen Ron
talker.role: Leader of The Nationals in the Senate
talker.name: Senator BOSWELL

talk.start.para: —I want to quote a ministerial statement from the Queensland Premier, Peter Beattie, on 22 March this year:

quote.para: Today I congratulate Griffith University researchers led by Professor Alan Mackay-Sim for having grown adult stem cells harvested from the olfactory mucosa in the nose. They demonstrated the cells can give rise not only to nerve cells but also to heart, liver, kidney and muscle cells. A paper on their work is … published … in peer-reviewed life sciences journal Development Dynamics.

Professor Mackay-Sim, deputy director of the university’s Institute for Cell and Molecular Therapies, has spent the past four years developing the research which will have potential clinical application in stem cell transplantation therapies and in understanding the biology of diseases.

Professor Mackay-Sim says the discoveries highlighted significant advantages of these adult stem cells over embryonic stem cells … The research suggests that these adult olfactory stem cells have the same ability as embryonic stem cells in giving rise to many different cell types but have the advantage that they can be obtained from all individuals, even older people who might be most in need of stem cell therapies.

This would mean that stem cells obtained from and transplanted into the same person would not be rejected by the immune system. For the past three years Professor Mackay-Sim’s research team has been investigating the potential of olfactory stem cells in treating Parkinson’s disease and is currently using stem cells from Parkinson’s sufferers to gain insights into the causes of the disease.

Professor Mackay-Sim, who was Queenslander of the Year in 2003, has been researching the sense of smell for 30 years, the past 20 focusing on the regeneration of the sensory nerves of the olfactory mucosa …
I congratulate the university and the professor. They are a perfect example of the Smart State in operation. They are brilliant and they deserve public acclaim.

speech.para: What I have just read from is a ministerial statement on the truly remarkable research going on in Queensland that has broken new ground in stem cell technology—using adult stem cells.

It is now established fact that adult stem cells are a viable alternative to the ethically problematic embryonic stem cells. They have worked out how to grow them quickly and easily and without the problems associated with embryonic cells of uncontrolled growths and tumours. Most importantly they can be grown from the patient’s own nose, making them good candidates for cell transplantation therapies and tissue reconstruction. You do not have the massive problem of rejection that you get with embryonic cells.

Because they can be grown without animal cells, there is also no risk of the transfer of animal genes or viruses during the growth of the cell. In addition, these adult stem cells are a wonderful source of cells to study diseases. The Griffith University research team is already using their 50 cell line population to investigate Parkinson’s disease, schizophrenia, motor neurone disease, epilepsy and others. There is no need for therapeutic cloning in order to study diseases, which is the main argument being put forward.

The consultant neurologist to the Mackay-Sim lab, Professor Peter Silburn, has also presented findings to a major international conference showing that stem cells derived from Parkinson’s disease patients, when transplanted into animal models, demonstrated marked improvement. This highlights the effectiveness of the adult stem cell approach. Internationally, trials are already under way using adult stem cells to study other diseases, such as heart disease. No-one is using embryonic stem cells to put back into humans.

I began by quoting the Queensland Premier’s enthusiastic praise for these researchers to show the bipartisan support that is developing for adult stem cell technology. A few years ago, the talk and the investment money was all for embryonic stem cell research. The talk was of cures, cures and more cures, for everything from spinal paralysis to motor neurone disease, Alzheimer’s, cerebral palsy, Parkinson’s and so on. It was the irresistible appeal of cures that pulled many votes over the line in support of the research legislation.

Now we have the Lockhart review to look at how the legislation on embryo research and cloning is working and whether there need to be changes. There has been a push from some to open the doors to cloning for research but not for reproduction purposes. Before we go down that track, there are some key questions that need to be answered. Firstly, where are the cures? Where are the research proposals for cures? Where are the peer-reviewed papers on cures? What disease has been seriously studied? Where are the human trials?

The answers are all coming from the adult stem cell field. Humans are constantly regenerating their own stem cells. They can be taken from a patient in 10 minutes. They can be grown into their thousands within weeks, not months as is the case with embryonic cells. They can be sent by mail to researchers studying disease all over the world. Some of the states’ arguments for cloning are a direct repeat of mantras heard last time: we will not be able to compete internationally unless we have cloning, we will lose our brainy people overseas and so on.

These claims are contradicted by the Commonwealth government’s Invest Australia publication entitled ‘Australian biotechnology—number one in the Asia Pacific for biotechnology investment’. The paper says:

quote.para: Ernst & Young ranks Australia as the number one biotech country in the Asia-Pacific and sixth worldwide in its global biotech census.
This is because Australia has a critical mass of international biotechnology organisations, which are generating 67 per cent of total public biotechnology revenues for the Asia Pacific region.
With a population of just over 20 million, Australia has only 0.3 per cent of the world’s population yet we produce 3 per cent of the world’s medical research.
Australia is in the top five countries (with population 20 million or more) in terms of availability of R&D personnel.
Australia also has a greater availability of scientists and engineers than the UK, Singapore and Germany.
Australia is ‘punching above its weight’ in biotechnology research.
Australian governments have assisted the biotechnology industry to grow by providing close to A$1 billion in public biotech-related expenditure …
Australia has around 400 companies (an increase from 250 in 2001) whose core business is biotechnology.

speech.para: Contrary to the scenario painted by some state premiers, Invest Australia says:

quote.para: Australia is cementing its place at the forefront of stem cell research with a transparent regulatory system and the establishment of the visionary Australian Stem Cell Centre (ASCC).

Australia offers the perfect platform for biotech investment, with the combination of skilled personnel, advanced technology, economic stability, scientific excellence and regulatory certainty. The Australian Stock Exchange Healthcare and Biotech Index has expanded to include 134 companies in the second quarter of 2004 with a market capitalisation of $27.1 billion.
Australian life science stocks gained 41.5 per cent in the financial year ending 30 June 2004 ...

speech.para: So the real Australian biotech market performance is buoyant and healthy, and not one that is pining away because of lack of cloning. The NHMRC Licensing Committee has issued nine licences to use excess ART embryos over the period to March 2008, involving up to 1,740 human embryos. The licence holders are: Sydney IVF, which has four; Melbourne IVF, which has two; Monash IVF, which has one; IVF Australia, which has one; and Monash University, which has one. As Professor Michael Good of the Queensland Institute of Medical Research notes in his submission to the Lockhart review:

quote.para: I am not aware of any clinical trials being undertaken or being planned using stem cells derived from IVF embryos, which was a major reason put forward in support of the legislation passed in 2002. The scientific hurdle was, and remains, immunological rejection and the scientific community is no closer to solving that dilemma. Until it does, I, as an immunologist, cannot foresee any clinical use for IVF-derived ES cell tissues without the concurrent use of powerful immunosuppressive agents.

speech.para: Professor Good goes on to say:

quote.para: ... possible ways to avoid an immunological rejection do exist. One approach is to create a very large bank of embryos (several million) that between them would contain one that had the correct immunological match for any given patient.

speech.para: He says that that seems patently impossible from a practical point of view. He continues:

quote.para: A different approach would be to use therapeutic cloning. A major ethical issue, from my perspective, is that at our current level of knowledge, to make such clones requires a source of ova (egg cells). These can be harvested from volunteers, but not in sufficient numbers if this approach is to be made widely available. There is also the significant personal sacrifice that women would need to make in donating ova to develop a therapy for another person.

speech.para: Due to cloning inefficiencies, enormous amounts of eggs would be required and they would only come from thousands of hyperovulated women during a medically risky procedure. In the UK a cloning team said that IVF eggs may not be sufficient. The Times online reported that Professor Murdoch said that she could not rule out asking for egg donations for research from women who would not otherwise be having such a procedure. That is the reality of therapeutic cloning. Do we want that situation in Australia? That is the direction in which therapeutic cloning would take us. Professor Good says:

quote.para: ... a further source of ova is from animals. Tissues derived from these clones would have a small component of animal genetic material and society would have to weigh the benefits with the potential risks. The issue that will confront most people, however, is what if the clone that was destined to become a tissue through therapeutic cloning, was instead implanted into a woman’s uterus by an unscrupulous doctor and allowed to develop into a child. This scenario would be totally unacceptable to the vast majority and Government would need to develop a method to police such activities.

speech.para: Embryo researchers are already talking about putting human genetic material into rabbit eggs to produce the clones. This analysis of the pitfalls ahead for the therapeutic application of embryonic stem cell research is quite staggering in its implications. It explains why we have seen no signs of cures, why there are not even developed research proposals for preclinical trials and why embryo research investors are calling for cloning.

It seems that the difficult debate the nation went through a few years ago has, in the end, been about a mere nine licences, nearly all to the benefit of IVF corporate interests. I will leave others to work out who they are. Professor Loane Skene, who is a member of the Lockhart committee, on 1 March 2000 told a House of Representatives inquiry into cloning:

quote.para: If there is to be legislation, I think it should be limited to preventing cloning for reproductive purposes. With regard to other aspects of cloning research and development, it seems to me that there is great potential. It is an area for research and treatment and it is an area that is very rapidly developing.

speech.para: So already we know where one member of the Lockhart committee stands on therapeutic cloning.

The last debate was a very difficult one for many of us and led to deep soul searching about the ethical issues involved. My point is that, for all the pain we went through and for all the costs, we are not even close to the promised cures from embryo research. Yet there is true hope out there. Medical research will tackle the most painful and debilitating diseases known to humanity. And it will do it through adult stem cell technology. The only question is: how long before the world wakes up to it? We have before us a sober opportunity to change direction to a zone of scientific research that is free of ethical dilemmas. I have taken several people to visit the leading adult stem cell laboratory at Griffith University to see at first hand the work being done there. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.

para.inline: The remainder of the speech read as follows—

quote.para: It is impressive to see how they grow these adult stem cells into liver, heart, kidney, muscle and nerve cells. They study diseases, they are in clinical trials.

Given that adult stem cells are a better alternative to cloning, I believe that this is the way to sidestep the ethical dilemmas and we should seize it. We should back the Australian adult stem cell scientists to the hilt. We would be doing the whole world a favour.

subdebateinfo.title: Professor Barry Marshall and Dr Robin Warren
Awards for Science
Medical Research

talk.start.para: —I continue the theme of Senator Boswell’s speech today on outstanding Australian science. Today I would like to recognise some of our outstanding contributors. Yesterday, as we all know, was a very exciting day for Australian science because Australia added to its already formidable and forever growing list of Nobel prize laureates. Professor Barry Marshall and Dr Robin Warren were awarded the 2005 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine and became our ninth and 10th Nobel laureates.

speech.para: Barry Marshall and Robin Warren proved that the bacterium Helicobacter pylori was the cause of stomach ulcers and gastritis. Prior to their discovery of this bacterium in the stomach, it was believed that stress and lifestyle were the major causes of peptic ulcer disease. In fact, it was said that the causes of stomach ulcers were due to ‘hurry, worry and curry’. Professor Marshall and Dr Warren permanently changed this prevailing view. The foundation for their breakthrough was laid in 1981 when a young Marshall met Warren, who was a Royal Perth Hospital pathologist with an interest in gastritis. Together they set out to investigate the possible connection between a microbe and ulcers. Dr Warren had observed small curved bacteria colonising the lower part of the stomach in around half of the patients studied. It was here that the crucial observation was made—that the signs of inflammation were always present in the gastric mucosa close to where the bacteria was seen. With that began the study of biopsies from 100 patients and after much effort they successfully managed to cultivate the bacteria and by doing so made it amenable to scientific study.

These two medical pioneers were so confident in their discovery that in 1984 Professor Marshall swallowed a culture of Helicobacter pylori to give himself gastritis, which is a precursor to stomach ulcers, and then cured it with antibiotics. Not only did this brazen act convince the most hardened sceptics, but it also gave Professor Marshall a new empathy for those who had been suffering the debilitating pain of stomach ulcers for many years. It was surely a selfless act that has gone down in medical folklore.

Their discovery was very much a sea change in scientific thinking as they were now able to demonstrate not only that bacteria could survive in a highly acidic stomach but that it was the spiral-shaped, Gram-negative bacterium that colonises the stomach in around 50 per cent of all humans and that some 10 to 15 per cent of infected individuals will, at some time, experience peptic ulcer disease. As the Nobel prize press release stated:

quote.para: Thanks to the pioneering discovery by Marshall and Warren, peptic ulcer disease is no longer a chronic, frequently disabling condition, but a disease that can be cured by a short regimen of antibiotics and acid secretion inhibitors.

speech.para: Our congratulations go to Professor Marshall and Dr Warren for their wonderful work.

Last night I attended the Prime Minister’s Awards for Science where I was fortunate enough to listen not only to a speech by Professor Marshall, who flew in from Western Australia specifically for the occasion, but also to addresses from a number of prize recipients who have made an exceptional contribution to Australian science. I was seated next to Professor Graham Farquhar, from the Environmental Biology Group in the Research School of Biological Sciences, who has been working with Dr Josette Masle and together they have discovered the gene called erecta that regulates water efficiency in plants. I spoke about that amazing work, which may lead to the development of drought resistant crops, during my speech here in National Science Week.

The ceremony was hosted by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki who taught us interesting scientific facts last night such as why a strapless dress stays up, why the use of a colon in the title of one’s work increases the number of citations, and the existence of a link between academic success and the excuse that one’s grandmother has died. A number of scientists were honoured. The Prime Minister’s Prize for Science was awarded to Professor David Boger. The Science Minister’s Prize for Life Scientist of the Year was awarded to Dr Harvey Millar. The Malcolm McIntosh Prize for the Physical Scientist of the Year went to Associate Professor Cameron Kepert. The Prime Minister’s Prize for Excellence in Science Teaching in Primary Schools went to Mr Mark Merritt, and the Prime Minister’s Prize for Excellence in Science Teaching in Secondary Schools was awarded to Mr Mike Roach.

The role of science teachers can never be overstated. It is their knowledge and experience coupled with limitless enthusiasm, tenacity, passion and patience that are cultivating and developing tomorrow’s scientists and future Nobel laureates. Their job is certainly not an easy one. They have to convert complex scientific concepts and ideas into easily digestible and, most importantly, engaging topics for their students. In fact, research demonstrates that the more positive experience a student has of science in school, the more likely they are to pursue a career in science in later life. For this reason I would like to single out for special mention and commendation the winners of the Prime Minister’s Prize for Excellence in Science Teaching in primary and secondary schools announced last night.

Mr Mark Merritt received the primary school award. He teaches at Marmion Primary School in the northern suburbs of Perth and has been teaching primary school students for 21 years. Mark was inspired to become a science teacher by the positive learning experience given to him by his year 7 teacher. In his words:

quote.para: He allowed us to investigate and explore the world around us, and was one of the many teachers to inspire me towards a science teaching career.

speech.para: Mark believes that it is fundamental for science teachers to answer questions not with ‘I don’t know’ but rather with ‘let’s find out’. I think that this comment sums up the ethos of Australian scientists—their inquisitive nature, their drive to find out the nature and cause of things and their reluctance to simply accept things at face value. It surely is that ‘let’s find out’ mentality that has seen us leave our planet and conquer once terminal illnesses.

As testament to Mark Merritt’s teaching ability and passion, his school dominated the Western Australia talent search, with one-third of the 28 children who took part in the competition winning prizes and around 80 per cent of them reaching the state finals. His school also won the overall prize for best primary school in the talent search.

It is also worthwhile to note on the record that Mark is a writer and trial teacher for the new national curriculum resource Primary connections: linking science with literacy. He is helping teachers implement new and exciting ways of teaching science and as such his zeal and enthusiasm is not just confined to the students fortunate enough to have him as a teacher but is dispersed Australia wide.

Mr Mike Roach, who won the secondary school award, teaches at Hamilton Secondary School in Adelaide and runs an annual space science school in South Australia. Mike fell into science teaching in 1971 when, while part way through a chemical engineering degree, he heeded the call from the South Australian education minister for anyone who had completed the first year of a university science course to assist in science teaching. That was 34 years ago, and that passion that drew him to teach is also what led him to be selected for this prestigious teaching prize.

Mike has been involved with the introduction of conceptual physics, which uses analogies and real world situations to explain physical principles. He has found that by using space as a base point he can explain practically all basic physics in a way that is exciting and engaging for his students. He believes that a critical shortage of teachers is the greatest threat to science teaching to confront Australia today. As he said last night:

quote.para: It’s important that we instil the next generation of students with a love of science, and that we give them the knowledge and problem-solving skills they will need to enable them to assess the impact of science and technology on their lives.

speech.para: How right you are, Mr Roach. I congratulate him and Mr Merritt on their awards and wish them the best of luck for the future.

We have a lot of other home grown research in science and medicine going on, and I want to reflect on two research topics today. The growing epidemic of diabetes already affects over a million Australians and twice that number are at risk of developing diabetes in the next five to 10 years. Despite the clear and present danger of diabetes, the role of high sugars in causing blindness, kidney failure and heart disease is poorly understood.

Dr Merlin Thomas, working at the Baker Heart Research Institute in Melbourne, has found a novel link between sugar and the complications that it causes. His diabetes research has found a link between protein modified by high sugar levels and organ damage. He has found that high sugar levels change or modify protein, which in turn goes on to cause damage to the organs in the body. He is working on a way to stop high sugar levels in the blood affecting the protein. To use an analogy, he says high blood sugar is like adding petrol to a fire. The high blood sugar fuels the creation of destructive modified protein. His research is looking to contain the fire no matter what is added to it, thus negating the effect of high sugar levels.

As well, he is developing a test that medical practitioners will be able to use on diabetes suffers to see how much of the modified protein is in their system, and thus doctors will be able to easily and quickly ascertain the level or risk of organ damage in their patients. Medical practitioners can also use Dr Thomas’s test on patients who are at risk of contracting diabetes to ensure that their organs do not start to deteriorate as a result of the disease. Dr Thomas has recently received a Victorian award for his research.

I have recently been able to find out a lot more about the work of Professor Michael Morgan, head of neurosurgery at the University of Sydney and the cerebrovascular neurosurgeon at Royal North Shore and Dalcross hospitals in Sydney. Since graduating in medicine from the University of Sydney in 1980, Professor Morgan has pursued his interest in neurosurgery, and was awarded a doctorate in medicine from the University of Sydney in 1991 for his study of human cerebral arteriovenous malformations.

Professor Morgan’s groundbreaking neurosurgery has saved thousands of lives. He specialises in the treatment of arteriovenous malformations, cerebral aneurysms and surgery for stroke—including bypass surgery, carotid endarterectomy and brain haemorrhage. Aneurysms resemble bubbles or focal dilations of arteries that occur at weak points of the artery wall. The likely reason for their formation is an interaction of many factors. Basically, they occur at points where there is the greatest stress on the artery walls, where arteries branch or change direction.

Aneurysms can lead to trouble if they rupture, if they increase in size or if solid material from within breaks off and travels downstream to block an artery to cause a stroke. The most common cause for trouble is haemorrhage caused by aneurysm rupture. It is uncommon to diagnose an aneurysm before it has ruptured and most people with an aneurysm are totally unaware that they have one until it bursts.

Professor Morgan has gained a world wide reputation for performing and teaching endovascular surgery. As the range and complexity of neurosurgical techniques and procedures has grown, it has become increasingly difficult for neurosurgeons to maintain expertise in all areas of neurosurgery, and he is regarded as a pioneer of modern neurosurgical techniques. He is sharing his expertise, teaching both here and overseas.

As you can see, Australian science is alive and well and we are proudly receiving an increased level of international recognition. As Senator Boswell so rightly said, we are really punching above our weight in our contribution to global science. We do very well with the funding we have for medical and science research. Imagine what we could do, however, if the sector was adequately funded. Our success is an indicator that we have enormous untapped human intellectual capacity in this nation. Increased funding in medical research could unleash this potential. I call on the government to increase investment in health and medical research to bring Australia up to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average of 0.2 per cent of gross domestic product.

I am also concerned about the government’s proposal to implement a radical new formula for the distribution of research grants, which includes the abolition of the Australian Research Council Board so that control over research grants will be with the minister. With the ARC abolished, the independent peer review process goes and political favouritism and agendas come in that, unfortunately, I can see will be awash with extreme pursuits. In this proud week of scientific research successes, I sincerely hope that, as well as celebrating the achievements of many hardworking Australians that have had their work recognised locally, nationally and internationally, we ponder our future and the future that we can foster for our scientists. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to speak again today on the dangers of giving not just this government but any government open-ended powers without proper scope for independent oversight of how those powers are exercised and proper opportunities for appeal when they are misused. This is relevant, of course, in the current debate around the so-called intelligence and security matters and the proposals by the Labor state and territory premiers and chief ministers and, of course, the federal Liberal Party government, to dramatically increase the powers available to a range of government officers and to the government.

speech.para: The big concern, as I said earlier today in a debate on the intelligence services legislation, is not just what the powers are but whether there is any scope for making sure that they are not misused. It is important to note that there are already significant examples of the government misusing the open-ended powers that they already have. I used the example this morning of the Tampa. Whatever people might think about the immigration policies surrounding boat people, the simple fact is that, in addressing the political issue of the Tampa, the federal government used a whole range of information that was gathered by intelligence agencies to inform their political response to that situation.

Communications between Australian citizens, between lawyers and their clients, by foreign companies, the shipping line and, almost certainly, the Norwegian government officials as well, were all intercepted and monitored, and the material was provided to government ministers and officers. Intelligence agencies were used to gather information to assist the government in its political response. A simple thing like not being able to be confident that your communications as an Australian with your legal representative are safe from monitoring—and not only monitoring but from being passed on to government officials—is a serious problem.

I will come back to that specific example later, but I want to emphasise that the Migration Act as a whole provides a range of case studies of what happens when you give open-ended powers to government ministers and officers. You get grotesque injustices, a lack of concern for the human consequences of decisions and an inability to have those injustices addressed or even identified in some cases.

I had a report forwarded to me today by the helpful people from the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. It was a report on the ABC web site that goes into a full Federal Court decision back in July about a man who is a Swedish citizen but who had actually lived in Australia for all but the first four weeks of his life. His parents are actually Australian citizens of Swedish origin and just happened to be in Sweden when he was born. They returned to Australia with him as a newborn baby, a few weeks old, and he had lived in Australia ever since. Despite that fact, he never actually took out Australian citizenship. Of course, we all know that there are many thousands of people in similar circumstances and who have lived here the vast majority of their lives but have never actually taken out Australian citizenship. This person committed some serious criminal offences in his adult life and was tried and jailed for those offences.

What we have in the Migration Act is, in effect, a form of double punishment, because not only do people get the court’s punishment but then, as a consequence completely separate of that process, they can get the government’s or the minister’s punishment. What happened in this case was that the person then had his right to remain in Australia cancelled, and he was required to depart Australia and go back to Sweden. He was basically being forced back to Sweden, despite the fact that the person had never lived there, did not speak Swedish, had no immediate family there and not just his parents but all of his family were in Australia. Obviously, anything that may have influenced him in the crimes that he committed was a result of his life here in Australia.

But the fact is that the minister does have an open-ended power, under the character provisions of the Migration Act, to simply cancel a person’s visa if the minister believes they have failed the so-called character test. The full Federal Court decision in this case has ruled that that was done unlawfully by the department. The government is appealing that decision in the High Court, so we shall see what happens there. But there is a broader principle here, beyond what happens to this individual, and that is that there is an open-ended power—and depending on how this appeal goes, it may continue to remain open-ended—for the minister to cancel the visa of a person under the so-called character provisions of the Migration Act. These are provisions, I might say, that were brought in with the support of the Labor Party, as well as the Liberal Party, as occurs with many of the unjust areas of the Migration Act.

The fact is that this is not a new scenario. Indeed, this case was referred to in the hearings last week before the Senate committee that is looking into the administration of the Migration Act. I would encourage those who are interested in this issue to look at the evidence given by Mr Glenn Nicholls from the Swinburne University of Technology’s Institute for Social Research. He has been looking into a range of similar cases.

I draw the Senate’s attention to a man by the name of Rodrigo Herrera, who, in similar circumstances, had his residency cancelled by the government on character grounds. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald in April last year by Cynthia Banham detailed his case. He moved here when he was six with his parents and siblings. His family subsequently applied for and received citizenship, but he neglected to do so. Mr Herrera got involved in some illegal activity and was tried and punished for that. His residency was subsequently cancelled and he was going to be deported to Chile. Having not lived there since he was six years old, his ability to speak the language of that country was less than adequate and he knew nobody there at all.

This is not just about the impact on the person; it is also about the impact on the wider family and the grotesque extra injustice, disproportionate punishment and impact that are placed on them. In a political sense, it is obviously hard for politicians to defend the rights of people who have committed crimes, because they are immediately attacked for standing up for criminals and wrongdoers. People ask, ‘Why shouldn’t we have people like that removed from the country?’ Frankly, from my point of view, if Australia has been responsible for bringing up a person, then it should be its system of justice that punishes them if they have committed a crime. Once they have done their time they have the right to get on with their lives in the same way as anybody else who commits a crime. But this group of people are at risk of, and sometimes subjected to, having the vastly greater and extra punishment of being permanently removed from Australia—not only deported but also never allowed to return. They are separated from their family, potentially permanently, unless their family want to move as well. That, I would suggest, is a grossly disproportionate punishment for any wrongdoing. The case of the Chilean man that I mentioned was challenged in the courts and failed. The judge at that time said that there were strong grounds for the government to reconsider the relevant section of the Migration Act and how it applies.

Another case that I am aware of, from 2004, involved a person that came here as a teenager from the UK. Again, the challenge in the Federal Court was unsuccessful, but I will read some comments from the judgment to emphasise the total power, the absolute power, that exists in these cases. It states:

quote.para: ... the exercise of the Minister’s power under s 501(2) of the Migration Act to cancel a visa can have profound consequences for permanent Australian residents. The exercise of the power can even affect people who have lived in this country since infancy. If the power of cancellation is exercised by the Minister personally under s 501(2), no merits review is available in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or elsewhere ... the failure of the Minister to give reasons for his or her decision to cancel a visa does not ... invalidate the decision. Thus a permanent Australian resident—

speech.para: who has lived basically their entire life here and whose family are here and are Australian citizens—

quote.para: may be removed from Australia without ever having been told why the Minister has exercised his or her discretion to cancel the visa.

speech.para: That has happened a number of times and it continues to happen. It is my view that it is not only a gross injustice, disproportionate to anything a person may have done, but also damaging to the overall fabric of the Australian community to have permanent residents able to be removed at the whim of a minister without any scope for oversight of how that power is exercised.

I am aware of another man, originally from Scotland, I think, who came here as a teenager. He is now nearly 50. He was sentenced to jail for breach of an apprehended violence order—obviously an inappropriate act—for which he was tried and punished. Subsequent to that, when he was released and living with his aged parents, who were quite ill, he was rearrested by immigration officers and taken to the Villawood Detention Centre, where he has remained for over 2½ years. Under his initial sentence he was in prison for well less than a year; he was then, or has been, in effect, imprisoned in Sydney for 2½ years. As we all know, unlike for prison, the government does the kind and helpful thing of charging people for every day they are in immigration detention. Although I cannot do the maths off the top of my head, at $180 a day for being detained at the minister’s pleasure in the detention centre, that person would have racked up a pretty large bill whilst trying to prevent himself from being sent back to a country where he has not lived for decades and where he has no family left, and while he has aged parents who are ill here in Australia.

These are gross injustices. The fact that they occur to people who have committed offences in Australia does not in any way reduce the size of them. I think it offends very important principles of public administration and due process of law that people can have such massively harmful and enormous things done to them at the whim of a minister who does not even have to justify their decision, which cannot be challenged. This is one area and one example of what can happen. But I should add to it the very significant fact that recent High Court judgments also suggest that it is quite possible for ministers to also cancel the citizenship of Australians or to have laws passed that will enable them to do so. Even though a person may be a citizen, the High Court’s recent decisions have made it apparent that ministers would be able to give themselves the power under law to deem that person an alien for the purposes of cancelling their citizenship, particularly if they held dual citizenship of another country.

I say all of this not only to point to injustices that occur under the Migration Act but also to sound a warning as to what can happen if we give extra powers to ministers, on so-called national security grounds, that allow people, on the basis of anonymous information, to be deemed a security risk through an intelligence agency that has no requirement to produce details of that anonymous information. We all know about the case of Mr Scott Parkin, the US peace activist, who was deported on grounds about which he was unable to be informed. That can be applied to permanent residents in Australia, who can then similarly have their permanent residence visa cancelled without any grounds being given to them.

That can happen now under the law, and it is quite feasible with future legal changes that it could even apply to Australian citizens who are deemed, according to a completely secret process, to somehow be security risks or to have failed character tests for other reasons. I would argue that that is an extremely dangerous power. We have already seen that it can be used, and has been used, in a way which causes massive injustices for people and for their wider families. That needs to be addressed and that situation needs to be removed from the Migration Act. We do not want to be expanding the scope for people to be removed from Australia, to even have their citizenship cancelled, on the basis of secret decisions that people have no right to appeal against. That is the risk we are facing, and we need to fight against it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Today I want to discuss the environment. On the weekend just past, the Liberal Party in Western Australia held a state conference. Indeed, I pause to say that the Liberal Party in Western Australia can hold a state conference, in stark contrast to my Labor colleagues who have some difficulty holding a state conference for fear of actual violence amongst the factions. At that state conference we passed a resolution in support of the mining and exporting of uranium. That is what I want to talk about today. The 300 delegates, if my memory serves me correctly, unanimously supported the proposition that we should get on with the job and start mining and exporting uranium. This is in stark contrast to Labor’s absolutely ridiculous, irrational and illogical three-mines policy, which each state Premier is seeking to maintain to shut out good viable jobs and to prejudice the development of a strong industrial section in this area.

speech.para: Australia has 30 per cent of the world’s uranium reserves. Australia produces and exports 10,000 tonnes of uranium oxide every year now, as I stand here and talk. Australia’s uranium is used solely for the generation of electricity right around the world. We apply the strictest guidelines and protocols to ensure that none of our exports find their way into countries like North Korea or Iran or, indeed, into weapons or any other misuse of this mineral. In the last five years, we have exported a total of 46,000 tonnes of uranium oxide, and this is in contrast to the Labor premiers saying, ‘No more uranium mining.’ It is already happening, and there is a demand in the world for our uranium. As I said, we have 30 per cent of the world’s reserves.

Our three producing mines were, until relatively recently, Ranger, Nabarlek, which is now closed, and Olympic Dam in South Australia. Our customers over the years have included Japan, Finland, France, South Korea, the United States, Canada, Sweden, the United Kingdom and Belgium. In Western Australia we have two world-class proven deposits: Yeleerie in the north-eastern goldfields of Western Australia and Kintyre in the East Pilbara shire of Western Australia. Western Australian reserves, as proven in those two deposits, are estimated to have an in-ground value of $6 billion, whilst the Northern Territory reserves currently have an in-ground value of about $12 billion. Western Australia has over 250 highly prospective mineralised areas which host uranium and other associated minerals.

The reason why we in Western Australia are so keen to look at this topic is that, as anyone who knows anything about China and, indeed, East Asia as a whole would be aware, there is a massive air quality problem. There is a huge build on in China—some 30 new reactors at a cost of $A64 billion are going to be rolled out in the next 10 years. Western Australia and indeed the whole of Australia need to be a part of what is happening with respect to energy generation, particularly in East Asia.

I now turn to the quite interesting recent events surrounding former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, when he made a call for the storage in Australia of internationally generated radioactive waste. I was watching the former Prime Minister on television, and I must confess to being marginally cynical. I thought that what he was doing was only seeking to distract from the current furore arising from The Latham Diaries to give the now leader of his struggling party some breathing space. Of course, he did touch on—and I trust that he is sincere; I want him to be sincere because this is a very important debate—the storage of not just radioactive waste but toxic liquid solid waste generally, which is a major issue for Australia and for Australians.

I pause to say that, in terms of the storage of radioactive waste, Australia has pioneered a vitrification process called synroc, which locks up the dangerous radionuclides in a crystalline structure which, as nearly as possible, replicates the natural state of radioactive minerals prior to mining. A group of minerals that has the capacity to lock up those radionuclides is, for example, the pyrochlore group of minerals. Synroc is on the cutting edge and is world’s best practice in lead technology as to the storage and handling of high-level radioactive waste.

There is an enormous number of issues surrounding this subject, as former Prime Minister Hawke indicated, including transport, storage and all the surrounding protocols, rules and regulations. But this is a debate that Australia should have. And why should we have it? It is because our cities have thousands of tonnes of low-level and high-level toxic and radioactive waste being stored in their suburbs. There are substances such as PCBs, polychlorinated biphenyls, which would be highly dangerous and environmentally very serious if they were not handled properly and carefully. There are very large amounts of mercury in our suburbs, being by-products of our industrial processes. There are acids, including hydrofluoric acid, perchlorethylene and tetrachloroethylene, just to name a few. Were these substances to enter our watertables, there would be a major generational problem and a major environmental hazard long into the future.

In Western Australia, in the last five years we have had two major and serious environmental issues. The Brookdale waste disposal plant was simply an old sewage treatment plant that was converted by the Department of Environment in Western Australia to handle liquid toxic waste. In about 2001-02, lead levels 75 times higher than World Health Organisation limits were found at a local primary school adjacent to this facility. The Department of Environment in Western Australia has no long-term plan for the disposal and handling of liquid toxic waste or solid toxic waste and yet the Labor Party government in Western Australia say, ‘We will not allow uranium mining.’

On 15 February 2001 a small company which was storing toxic waste had a fire. It was found in a subsequent inquiry that that facility was storing large amounts of waste, far in excess of the Department of Environmental Protection licence regime that was in operation. The government had in fact sanctioned the breach of the licence. I pause to say that Labor, in power in Western Australia, have refused to compensate a neighbour to that fire who was wiped out and have refused to accept any responsibility for the ongoing management of these substances, yet they are opposed to the storage of radioactive waste in Australia and sit by and acquiesce on the illegal and improper storage of tonnes of problematic, highly toxic waste and other radioactive waste. The hypocrisy of Labor in Perth is unrivalled, particularly in contrast to the maintenance of their three-mines policy and their refusal to allow further uranium mining in Western Australia.

Indeed, Labor in Western Australia would have us believe that they are very environmentally conscious. Nothing could be further from the truth. In support of my allegation against them, let me recite to you what has been happening in Perth in the last four years, since Labor took over. Let us take our iconic Swan River in Perth, in Western Australia. There have recently been several large sewage spills. In September, just last month, an unknown quantity of raw sewage entered the Swan River at Bassendean through a stormwater drain due to some maladministration, neglect or foul-up in the Water Corporation’s sewerage management. In April this year, 250 kilolitres—that is, 250,000 litres—of raw sewage were pumped into the Swan River at South Perth through a stormwater drain. In October 2004, 2.5 million litres—that is, two Olympic size swimming pools—of raw sewage went into the Swan River. In 2003 there were three spills—in May, July and November—flooding 1.3 million litres of raw sewage into the Swan River. In January of that same year 50,000 litres went into the Swan River when a pump failed. In December 2001 we saw 160,000 litres spilled into the Canning River. In the last four years a total of over 4.2 million litres of raw sewage has entered the Swan River. This is the administration of Labor. This is the environmental awareness of Labor in Perth, in Western Australia.

Labor in WA have delayed the previous Court government’s infill sewerage program, which would have eliminated 111,000 septic tanks in backyards throughout suburban Perth, which would have substantially reduced the nitrogen and phosphorus levels in groundwater and entering the river. Labor have just said, ‘No, we’re going to do other things.’ This is the action of an environmental vandal as a government. It is against the backdrop of February 2000, when we had one of the worst toxic blue-green algae blooms—Microcystis aeruginosa—in the Swan River. You cannot swim in it, you cannot water ski on it, you cannot have anything to do with it. I am a sailor in Perth. The yacht club had to be closed because we could not sail on the Swan River because of the blue-green algae blooms. This is the background to Labor’s alleged environmental approach to stop uranium mining. They cannot look after domestic environment issues. They cannot be trusted with domestic environmental issues.

With all this sewage flowing into the Swan River, today the Water Corporation have announced a $420 million profit. What is happening to maintenance programming in their sewerage systems? It is simply outrageous. This is the record of a government that are opposed to uranium mining for stupid, crass, cheap, point-scoring, political motivations—a government in Western Australia that cannot manage their own environment in suburban Perth. It is a disgrace.

talk.start.para: —In recent sittings I have spoken a number of times about the record of the current government in the area of defence procurement activities. Thanks to the work of the Australian National Audit Office, we have a detailed record of a large number of exercises which really have gone off the rails. Moreover, by looking at each of these exercises individually, we can see a clear pattern of failure that has emerged. This is not a recent phenomenon. Failure to procure materiel on time and within budget is time honoured. Global budgets, single line appropriations and poor documentation make transparency extraordinarily difficult. We in the parliament therefore have limited ability to do much about this problem. That simply suits the government, as it is able to conceal its own bungling. It certainly would not be tolerated in any other portfolio, and any private sector company performing this way would be the subject of an ASX investigation as a matter of priority. Yet we are constantly told that Defence is different—there is no other operation like Defence anywhere; it is big, complex and holds $75 billion of Australian government assets. It is too big.

speech.para: Frankly, none of this argument—none of this defence—washes at all. It is simple failure at the political level to ensure administrative accountability. There is always an excuse. There is always a light at the end of the tunnel. At present, we are shifting the deckchairs for the newly commercialised, business orientated Defence Materiel Organisation—the DMO. We are told that we have a new two-pass system. We are also told that it is the answer to all of our prayers. Yet we in this place know that all this is rhetoric. We fear it will not make the slightest amount of difference at all. The reason for that assertion is that the culture of the organisation remains unchanged. It is too easy to hide behind the mystique and glory of the defence of our nation and the glory of our flag. There is always an excuse for inactivity.

The Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee reported on this subject in March 2003. Can anyone tell us what has happened to the recommendations of that particular report? The answer is: nothing. Senators might recall the recommendation that an annual report of progress on every capital acquisition project be prepared. What happened to that recommendation? That alone would help the parliament understand where tens of billions of dollars are being spent. Unfortunately, the fog still lies thick on that particular report.

At estimates every year we do our best to come to grips with the defence budget, including procurement policy. We are barely able to penetrate those reports. We receive plenty of bland assurances and generalities—and next time around it will be the same. In many cases the information sought is simply not available. The ANAO reports the same phenomenon—Defence simply do not know, nor do their contractors. I refer particularly to the report on the frigate upgrade project. What is presented as information in all the glossy documents and budget papers is incomplete. Sometimes it is contradictory. Often officials are unable to answer questions because they were not there at the time, there is no corporate memory or records do not exist. Regrettably, we do not have the resources we need to scrutinise; nor does the ANAO.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit is also trying to come to grips with this issue. The result is that, year after year, this performance on procurement staggers on. By the way, this is not just about a few million dollars. In report No. 35 of 2004-05, the ANAO quote the finding of the due diligence inquiry conducted in the lead-up to the inception of the Defence Materiel Organisation. That exercise found that, since 1981, the amount spent on the top 64 procurement projects had been $11.8 billion above the original estimated amount. We can only guess what it might have been for the entire capital works program over that time. No-one has yet asked to look at the minor projects.

It is relevant to note that the minister refused to answer a question from Senator Evans seeking information on cost blow-outs and delays on major capital projects. This was of course a complete fabrication, because the work had been done in the due diligence exercise for the DMO. This is simple deception. The government does not want anyone to know how bad things really are. More to the point, it is unknown what dilution of defence capacity has resulted. It is not the taxpayer who is being diddled here—it is the entire defence effort.

The glossy nature of the Defence Capability Plan is completely undermined by the repeated failure to deliver what is sought on time and at cost. In many cases, product specified at a price is both late and way over cost. Worse than this, cost cutting, which is the general solution, causes the order to be reduced and specifications to be deleted. The planned budget and capability are constantly compromised. Again, the frigate upgrade project is a classic example. Six frigates were contracted at an estimated cost of $890 million in 1997. The order was then reduced to four frigates at a cost today of almost $1.5 billion. Two-thirds of the budget will be spent by the end of this year, and not one ship has yet been delivered. A betting man would say that more of these ships will be mothballed yet. It goes without saying that this is a very serious issue and would not be tolerated in any public or private corporation outside government areas.

In passing, I should also mention that financial mismanagement is equally rampant. Huge sums of money have been paid in advance and have not been acquitted. Other equally large sums are parked in trust accounts to bypass the Treasury and to disguise low cash flow on slipping projects. However, I should say that we do accept that sometimes there might be mitigating circumstances. The key one which most frequently occurs is where there is advanced and perhaps as yet unknown technology. The very nature of defence activity is to maintain a critical edge. Where new technology is concerned, we know that around the world national defence provides the impetus for the adoption of that new technology. That in turn spins off into broader industry and eventually down the chain to consumer usage. Importantly for defence activity these days, it also significantly reduces the likelihood of casualties in an operational sense, hence the emphasis on remote control, reduced exposure and the use of the most sophisticated technology that is available.

Defence planners frequently ask their technical people to come up with things which are not yet in existence. Procurements such as these are therefore very difficult to cost but nevertheless require a commitment before the actual work can start. Aviation is one such area where new horizons are constantly being sought. The Joint Strike Fighter currently in design is perhaps a useful example in this context. Certainly, digital technology associated with radar, communications and weaponry is and will continue to be leading edge. Sadly, it also has a short life span with respect to obsolescence. Constantly we find that procurement plans are overtaken during development, although, it should be added, only because the delays accepted in the system make that outcome inevitable. So, sometimes, costs may be difficult to pin down early in the procurement cycle. Whether we accept that excuse, though, is debatable; it is up for argument. Certainly, manufacturers in the commercial market do not have that luxury. The lead times for commercial aircraft manufacture are similar, and companies such as Boeing manage in a fully competitive market and, I might add, have no problem tracking their stores and inventories, which are every bit as complex as those of Defence.

For those old enough it is worth remembering the decision to buy the F111. Speculation at that time concentrated on final price, its revolutionary swing wing design and its terrain-following radar capability. Yet that aircraft has become one of the most reliable and better performing aircraft of all time—so good, in fact, there are some who believe its planned service could be extended with a cost benefit over early purchase of the JSF. The debate we have now on the JSF was had then as well, in almost exactly the same terms. It may also be inevitable that, where there are drawn out planning and production schedules, current technology can be quickly superseded. The original systems in the Collins class submarines are a useful example. By the time construction was ready, computer technology had rendered the original obsolete; hence, extra cost down the line.

The longer the planning and construction phase the more likely this is to occur. Again, ANAO assessment is that time delays cause 89 per cent of cost overruns. The remainder is caused by added specification. In some cases, both these basic elements may be justified, but the overwhelming evidence is that they are not. Indeed, the most telling diagnosis of the Kinnaird report is that the most common failure is to get the original specifications correct; hence, the new two-pass system put up as a solution to this problem. Under this system initial approval is given to enable specifications to be accurately developed, followed by a second decision of commitment from government. Whether this will work is yet to be seen. But it does make sense to spend more on development up front prior to production rather than part way through. We simply could not imagine any commercial product manufacturer doing it any other way. There is more to this, though, and I will continue my remarks on this subject later this evening in the debate on the adjournment.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation
talker.name: Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: —In closing this debate on matters of public interest I want to commend Senator Johnston on his very thoughtful contribution on uranium mining in Australia. Senator Johnston very clearly articulated the absolute stupidity of the Labor Party’s position, where uranium from three mines in Australia seems to be okay but uranium from any other mine seems to be bad uranium. How anyone in the Labor Party can ever explain that policy is beyond me. I notice that many in the Labor Party never try to explain it, because they understand as well just what a stupid policy it is. I congratulate Senator Johnston on that very thoughtful address.

speech.para: It did bring to mind how divided the Labor Party is on this. Senator Johnston mentioned Mr Bob Hawke and his support for opening up the debate on more uranium mining. In Queensland, big Bill Ludwig, the head of the ACTU there for many years and the father of Senator Joe Ludwig, has come out very strongly in favour of uranium mining in that state. One would only hope that big Bill Ludwig, the AWU boss and heavyweight, would, at a family gathering, encourage his son Joe to support the same sort of proposal. Senator Joe Ludwig is, of course, part of the Labor Party in this parliament and he is a person who could, I think, very significantly contribute to the Labor Party getting a more sensible policy on uranium mining.

I noticed Mr Ludwig Sr, the AWU heavyweight, was in Mount Isa criticising very severely the Queensland Labor Premier, Mr Peter Beattie, for his closed shop view on uranium mining. Mr Ludwig Sr, the AWU heavyweight, clearly understands that it is ridiculous for Australia to deny itself the export dollars that would come from additional uranium mining. Furthermore, Mr Bill Ludwig, the AWU heavyweight, understands the importance of jobs to Queensland were we able to mine uranium in that state.

Over the years the AWU has had a very strong influence on the Labor Party in Queensland. As a result of that influence it has enabled many current senators from Queensland to be elected to this parliament. I hope that those senators from Queensland elected with the support and imprimatur of the AWU faction in Queensland heed the warning of Mr Ludwig Sr and do something about uranium mining and the ridiculous ALP policy. Mr Bill Ludwig understands that there is absolutely no sense or significance whatsoever in the Labor Party’s closed shop policy towards uranium mining in Australia. Mr Bill Ludwig also understands that jobs for Queenslanders are at risk because of the Labor Party’s policy. Mr Bill Ludwig has been very forthright in supporting uranium mining. I certainly hope that his son, Senator Joe Ludwig, who has now joined us in the chamber, will take up his father’s call and will criticise even harder Mr Beattie and the federal Labor leadership for their closed shop view on uranium mining. I hope that the Labor Party will join the government in a more expansive view on uranium mining for Australia.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator the Hon. Rod Kemp, Minister for the Arts and Sport, will be absent from question time from Wednesday, 5 October to Thursday, 6 October inclusive. Senator Kemp will be absent due to his attendance at the UNESCO conference in France on behalf of the Australian government. During Senator Kemp’s absence, Senator the Hon. Helen Coonan, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, has agreed to take questions on behalf of the portfolio of the arts and sport.

talker.name: Evans, Sen Chris
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
talker.name: Senator CHRIS EVANS

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Hill in his capacity as Minister for Defence and as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister indicate what steps the government has taken to encourage the Indonesian government to ban the terrorist organisation Jemaah Islamiah? Wouldn’t the act of banning this organisation send a very clear legal, political and moral message to the community, both in Australia and in Indonesia, that these sorts of organisations will not be tolerated? Wouldn’t it also allow Indonesia to shut down schools and training camps that are run by JI as recruitment centres for their terrorist network? Wouldn’t a comprehensive ban on JI also provide a criminal basis for Indonesian prosecutors to act against the organisation? Will the government now use its influence in the region to encourage the Indonesian government to take this most important step?

—I thank Senator Evans for his question. The Australian government will continue to urge the Indonesian government to strengthen further its counter-terrorism laws, including by outlawing Jemaah Islamiah. That would bolster the legal tools available to Indonesian authorities in pursuing the wider JI network and underline Indonesia’s resolve to fight terrorism. It would not of course in itself reduce the threat from JI as a secretive terrorist organisation increasingly working through loose networks drawing on individuals with no formal links to JI.

answer.para: The government is working closely with Indonesia and other regional countries to counter this evolving threat on a number of fronts. It has committed more than $250 million to this goal since 2004, including more than $50 million for Indonesia to boost counter-terrorism capabilities in areas like law enforcement, border control and transport security. It also includes enhancements of efforts with Indonesia and its neighbours to address terrorist movements between countries of the region for operations, training and refuge. We are also supporting efforts such as a regional interfaith dialogue to empower moderate voices to contest extremist ideologies peddled by JI and its supporters. Ultimately, Indonesians themselves will decide how best to fight this insidious threat, including how to treat JI as a terrorist organisation. In our view, it is important that all states make clear their profound disapproval of such organisations and their activities. Australia remains committed to playing its part in what will clearly be a long-term challenge.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Can the minister actually outline what steps the Australian government will take to encourage Indonesia to ban the terrorist organisation Jemaah Islamiah?

—Australia realistically cannot do more than make representations. We have made them in the past; we will continue to do so. I understand Mr Downer has indicated that he will be travelling to Indonesia to further press this issue. We do understand, and I acknowledged yesterday, the number of measures that Indonesia has taken to address this threat. We also understand the complexity in the issue of banning JI. If it were simple, Indonesia would have already done so. It is very reluctant to drive those who may support this organisation underground, for obvious reasons. It is also very reluctant to lose the support of a more moderate element of the community that may be on the fringe of these organisations. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Special Minister of State, Senator Abetz. Will the minister outline to the Senate how the Howard government intends to make Australia’s democracy fairer for all? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

—I thank Senator Troeth for her question and note her longstanding interest in electoral matters and in ensuring that we have a fair and robust electoral system in this country. The government is committed to improving Australia’s democracy and to creating a fairer electoral system for all. Last night at the Sydney Institute I outlined moves to ensure that we have an electoral roll which is both rigorous and fair.

answer.para: It is often said—and it is true—that it is easier to get onto the electoral roll than it is to hire a video. All one need do today to get on the roll is to sign the form and get someone else to witness it—it is not very rigorous at all. Just ask Mike Kaiser, the disgraced Labor roll rorter who is now chief of staff to the New South Wales Labor Premier. Those opposite might recall that Peter Beattie, the Premier of Queensland, said, ‘We will drum roll rorters out of the party.’ All they did was drum him over the state border and straight into the chief of staff position of the New South Wales Premier. Ask the Labor operative in Queensland that went to jail for roll rorting in the year 2000.

The government will move to tighten the requirements for getting on the electoral roll, requiring citizens to produce either a prescribed form of identification or to have someone from a prescribed class of witnesses vouch for their identity in the same vein as a statutory declaration. This is going to remove opportunities such as when in 1990 Curacao Fischer Catt—somebody’s pet—was put onto the electoral roll in the seat of Macquarie.

Another serious issue is the potential for the roll to be used to create false identities to help perpetrate other crimes, including social security fraud. For example, electoral enrolment can be used to count for 25 points in a 100-point identity check. I was also asked about alternative policies. I thought for the benefit of those opposite we would have another ‘Who said it?’ This was said about the Labor changes made in 1984:

quote.para: I concentrated on making more certain that Labor could embrace power as a right and make the task of anyone trying to take it from us as difficult as we could.

answer.para: Which person said that? It was a former Labor luminary in his autobiography—but, no, it was not Mark Latham. Those opposite know who it was, but they are too scared to name him. Of course, it was former Senator Graham Richardson on page 144 of his book Whatever it Takes. In a chapter entitled ‘Changing the rules’, he brags about the changes:

quote.para: Labor could embrace power as a right and make the task of anyone trying to take it from us as difficult as we could.

answer.para: Do you know who presided over those changes at the time? Who was the then Special Minister of State? It was the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, who is now railing against us seeking to introduce some integrity to the electoral roll. You would have thought that, with Labor having members of parliament resign and operatives go to jail, and having acknowledged and admitted publicly that they deliberately manipulated the electoral system for their own political advantage whilst Mr Beazley was Special Minister of State, if the man had some modicum of decency he would not have come out in this debate attacking our proposals, which are designed to make our system fairer and more robust. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to his comments yesterday, and similar comments by the Minister for Justice and Customs and others, that there was no specific intelligence that could have helped prevent the bombing in Bali last weekend. Is the government satisfied that Australia’s intelligence systems worked effectively, despite not being alerted to any real prospect of an imminent terrorist attack? Can the minister indicate whether the government plans to review Australia’s intelligence system to help ensure that the likelihood of advance warnings of further attacks in the future can be improved?

—I reflect back on the recent experience in London. Suicide bombers are very difficult to predict. We have substantially enhanced our intelligence coverage on the issue of terrorism within South-East Asia in recent years. We have significantly improved cooperation and communication with equivalent agencies in other South-East Asian countries. We certainly have a much enhanced picture of Jemaah Islamia than we had a few years ago. We know a lot about its structure, its leadership and its techniques. We have information on believed training establishments, particularly now outside of Indonesia. But, as I said yesterday, specific intelligence on a particular attack is rarely obtained in these circumstances. It was not obtained in Bali 1, it was not obtained in Madrid, it was not obtained in London, it was not obtained in Morocco, it was not obtained in Saudi Arabia, and unfortunately such information was not available in Bali 2.

answer.para: I have real confidence in Australia’s intelligence agencies. I think they are working exceptionally well in the Australian interest in terms of a better understanding of this terrorist threat in our region. There is obviously a great deal we now know that we did not know a few years ago, but unfortunately there will still be occasions when that critical bit of information simply will not be available, either to us or to, as in this case, Indonesia. In many ways you would expect it would come to the Indonesian authorities before the Australian authorities.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister indicate in his answer whether or not it warrants a review? Can the minister also explain today’s report in the West Australian newspaper that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is prepared to factor rumours into its travel advice? Can the minister indicate whether DFAT has now passed its knowledge of such rumours on to the Australian Federal Police for investigation, and when?

—Perhaps the most difficult issue of all is what to put in travel warnings. Obviously, soundly based intelligence would clearly be taken into account. Something that is less sound creates quite difficult circumstances and difficult judgments to be made. We rely on capable professional advice in this regard—in particular, the advice of the National Threat Assessment Centre, which, as I said, takes into account what threat information is known and sometimes other considerations as well. In the case of the travel advice for Indonesia of 3 October, it is a fact that there were reports of general and specific bomb and terrorist threats following the 1 October bombings and, in bringing some of these to the attention of the Australian public, it was also made clear that the government had nothing to corroborate such reports. I think that that gives Australians the best information that we have and therefore we meet our responsibility in doing so. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Will the minister update the Senate on recently announced reforms to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act? What is the nature of the proposed reforms and how will they benefit Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory? Is the minister also able to assure the Senate that the rights of traditional owners enshrined in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act will not be eroded as a result of government reforms?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
