talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Scullion, a senator for the Northern Territory with a long-standing interest in these issues, for the question. I will answer the second question first, and the answer is: yes, I can assure the Senate that the rights of traditional owners will in no way be interfered with by this legislation—in fact, quite the opposite. I am sure that Senator Scullion knows that what we are doing is creating opportunities for traditional owners to finally get some income from land in townships.

answer.para: It is understood that Aboriginal land can now be leased, but it is a long and difficult process. It can take two years to renegotiate a 10-year lease and seven years for other leases. This provides a very strong disincentive to people to engage in lease arrangements because they cannot do so with any security. And, of course, when you do not have security in respect of your lease, you do not put as much investment in. These changes will make it simpler and easier for township residents, either in businesses or homes, to get long-term leases.

The scheme is entirely voluntary. Nothing will change unless traditional owners want it to. In fact, it will operate in a way very similar to that operating in the ACT, where the government continues to own the underlying freehold title and people get a 99-year lease over the land—a leasehold interest. This scheme is not exactly the same as that but similar because, under the proposed scheme, the traditional owners will continue to hold the underlying communal title to the land. They will still own the land. Township residents would get a long-term lease over the land—a leasehold interest. The changes will not affect the traditional owners’ right of veto. The government will not compulsorily acquire Aboriginal land. We are simply providing an opportunity. At the moment, if you live in a township on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory and you want to buy your own home, you have to leave your community. Other people do not have to do that, and we want to change that.

The scheme will work like this: traditional owners will decide, voluntarily, if they want to do this. And what they could do is provide a head lease over a township to an organisation that would be set up by the Northern Territory government. That lease would be for 99 years. The traditional owners, in setting up that lease with the Northern Territory government organisation, could set other broad conditions of the lease, including rent of up to five per cent of the value of the land.

If town residents then want a long-term lease over their home or a business they apply to the Northern Territory organisation for a sublease. That will be quicker and more efficient than current arrangements. The traditional owners and the Northern Territory entity will do all the negotiations to set the terms of the head lease, and any subleases will be subject to those terms. In other words, traditional owners have all the control they want and need. There is no need for individuals then to go through protracted negotiations each time with traditional owners and land councils. They will only need to apply to the Northern Territory entity for a sublease.

This is about protecting the rights of traditional owners, and opening up new opportunities for them to get income and new opportunities for other people to have security of tenure over their home or their business where they can put in some investment, have some security and attract more investment. We are doing something here to empower Indigenous people, providing opportunities and choices.

I welcome the cautious support offered by Senator Evans in relation to this. It is a pleasant change from his remarks last night, which indicated there had not been adequate consultation on this issue—in fact, suggesting that these negotiations had been conducted in secret. But, be that as it may, I welcome the turnaround and I, of course, welcome the support of the Northern Territory government for this change. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister further inform the Senate of the impact of the amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act suggested today and, particularly, how they relate to further improvements in Indigenous communities in the Northern Territory?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Scullion. It is understood that what we are suggesting here is not a panacea for the economic circumstances of Aboriginal Territorians. If there was a magic wand someone would have found it by now, and this alone is not it. But it is a step in the right direction.

answer.para: In direct contrast to a press release put out by the Australian Democrats’ Senator Andrew Bartlett, headed ‘Aboriginal rights next to be attacked by extremist government’, in fact what is happening here is that legislation is being introduced to give further opportunities to first Australians—real opportunities. It will give them the same opportunities that people around Australia—including, for example, our friends from Warrnambool in the gallery—have: to have some security over the place where they live and where they work.

Remoteness and low education and employment levels are, of course, fundamental issues, and these reforms do not address those issues. But we do not resile from those difficult issues. There are other things to be done. But, if we can make this change, we will improve the situation. (Time expired)

talker.name: Evans, Sen Chris
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
talker.name: Senator CHRIS EVANS

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the minister indicate whether the government has confidence in the effectiveness of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade’s travel advisory system? Hasn’t the travel advisory for Indonesia, including Bali, recommended the deferral of all non-essential travel to that country for at least the last 12 months? Despite this strong warning, don’t thousands of Australians, including MPs from both sides of this parliament, continue to travel to Bali each year? Is the government now considering a further review of the travel advisory system, given that it appears not to have an impact on the travel plans of Australians?

—We see our responsibility as providing what information we know to the Australian public in order that they can take that into account in their travel plans. As Senator Evans has said, for some years we have been warning of the risks in relation to Bali and Indonesia generally. I think it is fair to say that Australians are generally aware of the general tenor of the travel advisory, and I think travel agents generally do make the travelling public aware. But the decision to travel is ultimately for the individual, and in our democracy we do not see it as the right or responsibility of the government to prohibit individual travel. So individuals will continue to make decisions taking into account the risks, and I do not think that that is in any way an indictment of the travel advisory.

answer.para: Some might say that that is the public taking undue risks. On the other hand, the public in many ways also has the right not to be intimidated by these threats and, in weighing the threats and determining not to be intimidated—to not allow terrorism to significantly alter their way of life—they are in fact not allowing themselves to be defeated by this threat. It is very difficult for the government to interfere in that thought process as well. So I think the travel advisories do their job. They inform the public, and I think each individual has the right to make their own decision about whether or not to travel after taking into account that information.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, but I think he missed the central tenet of the question, which is: how do you measure the effectiveness of these travel advisories? Do they do their job, given that so many Australians are ignoring the message contained in them; and is the government considering an alternative system that might be more effective? I would also ask him to advise what tests and checks are applied before information is included in travel advisories, and can he confirm that the basis for the latest updated travel advisory for Bali is media reports, not intelligence?

—In relation to the last point, I answered that in the previous question. It might have been that Senator Evans was thinking of something else. I do not see this as a criticism of the travel advisory. If there was evidence that people were unaware of the advice then there might be further steps that government could take. If there was evidence that people disbelieved it, perhaps there might be other ways to emphasise its importance—but I have not seen that evidence. I think people witnessed the experience of the first Bali attack, the horrors of the first Bali attack, in which 88 Australians were killed. They have seen a further attack on Australian interests, our own embassy in Jakarta late last year. They know of the attack on the Marriott in Jakarta. They know these threats exist within Indonesia but they were still determined to have their annual holiday, and it is their right to do so if that is their wish. They can take into account the travel advisories but, in the end, people are responsible for the decisions they make. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Ellison. Will the minister update the Senate on the Australian government’s response to the horrific Bali bombings of last Saturday evening?

—I thank Senator Mason for the question. Yesterday I advised the Senate that there were some 35 personnel in Bali representing Australian policing. That number has now risen to 41 and by tomorrow will be up to 45. Many of these officers have had experience, through our investigations of the Marriott bombing, the previous Bali bombing in October 2002 and of course the embassy bombing last year. We have now been joined by the British Metropolitan Police and the FBI, but I can say that in relation to foreign policing Australian police are the highest in number, and I think that is a significant aspect of the status we are given and the regard in which we are held in Indonesia. We continue to enjoy very close working relationships with the Indonesian authorities. And I can say that the diversity of expertise that we have there covers a broad range of policing activities, be it investigative, intelligence, forensic or indeed family liaison officers.

answer.para: I said yesterday that some 5,000 returning passengers have been interviewed. I can now say that 4,000 have completed questionnaires and, of those 4,000, 185 have provided information which is material to the investigation. As I have said, any information that the public can provide would be gladly accepted by the Australian Federal Police. We are leaving no stone unturned in the investigation of this matter and we are totally committed to bringing to justice all those who are responsible for this outrageous act.

There have been of course a number of rumours circulating, and I want to clarify at the outset that there has been no arrest to date in relation to this matter. Some people have been questioned; I understand that they have now been released. But I think that it is wise for people to rely on official statements from either the Indonesian National Police or the Australian Federal Police in this matter. It is quite normal in this environment for there to be rumours circulating but it certainly does not help matters that people act on rumours and regard them as fact when indeed they are not.

Some concern has also been expressed over the question of a remission for Abu Bakar Bashir. As applies in the Indonesian judicial system, on Idul Fitri at the end of Ramadan in November, there is an automatic remission which applies across the board to a variety of prisoners—and also on Indonesian Independence Day. We understand that, in the normal course of events, under the system Abu Bakar Bashir and 19 other convicted terrorists would benefit from these remissions and we have protested as such to the Indonesian government. This does not send a good message in relation to the fight against terrorism, and we are certainly checking our reports in Indonesia that the remissions will be applied.

I understand that the President, when he met with the Prime Minister on 16 September this year, indicated that he would review these remissions, and we continue to make representations in the strongest possible terms to Indonesia that remissions should not apply to anyone convicted of a terrorist offence and that, should it do so, it certainly sends the wrong message. But I can say that we continue to enjoy a very close working relationship with the Indonesian authorities and we have had nothing but the strongest commitment from them in their resolve to find those responsible for this outrageous attack.

talk.start.para: —My question is also to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Does the minister believe it is appropriate that, under section 7C of the Privacy Act, political acts or acts by political representatives are exempt, even when it may involve a politician, in this case a senator, deciding to disclose the personal medical information of a woman who has undergone a late-term abortion? I would like to know if the government thinks that that exemption is appropriate generally; but, specifically, was it intended to cover activities of that kind? When will this government consider amending the Privacy Act so that politicians like us are subject to the same privacy rules and principles that apply to everyone else in the private and public sectors?
—I must confess that the provisions of section 7C of the Privacy Act do not readily spring to mind, but I say that, in relation to the particular matter at hand—

—I alert Senator Evans to the fact that the Attorney-General has responsibility for privacy matters. In relation to the matter concerned, I am not aware of the detail of that. I acknowledge that Senator Stott Despoja has a long-standing interest in privacy matters, unlike others who profess to have so. In relation to the carrying out of our roles as members of parliament, we sometimes have to refer to issues which are in the public interest. The very fact that we have privilege in this chamber is a matter which is attendant upon our role, not because of who we are but what we are—that is, representatives.

answer.para: If you can talk on matters and they touch on matters of privacy, of course one should do so with some sensitivity. And we do so when we are talking about a range of issues, such as matters that are before the courts and other matters. If we were to be precluded from talking about matters of public interest across the board because of some privacy matter, it could well be that the interests of the public might not be served. As to the detail of this particular case, which I am not aware of, I will look into that and get back to Senator Stott Despoja in due course.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response, but ask him to not just take the matter on notice to provide more detail but investigate the issue. I ask again: even if the minister claims that it is in the public interest for politicians to have access to information, surely this government considers it inappropriate for politicians to be able to disclose sensitive—to use his words—medical personal information and get away with it because there is an exemption under the act that relates to political acts and practices. I am not suggesting that the act was illegal. In fact, the Privacy Commissioner has acknowledged that this is not within the jurisdiction of the act. So when will the government change the act to ensure that politicians are subject to the same rules as all other members of the public?

—I have given my assurance to the Senate that I will look into this matter, and I will do that, but we have referred to matters on many occasions without indicating who the individual is in order to demonstrate an issue which is being debated in this chamber. I look around this chamber and I can see many senators who have done that, and I could say not inappropriately so, because that has been to bring to the attention of this chamber and the parliament a matter of public importance. As to this particular issue, I will look into that and get back to the Senate.

—My question is the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Helen Coonan. Given the significant recent discussions on the impact of regulation on the telecommunications industry, will the minister update the Senate on how the government’s competitive regulatory regime is ensuring quality telecommunications services for all Australians? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts
talker.name: Senator COONAN

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ronaldson for his question and for his interest in these important issues. The answer is that I am aware of the discussions surrounding the effects of regulation on the telecommunications sector and I can inform the Senate that there is some material evidence that was released this week. The Australian Communications and Media Authority released its analysis of how telecommunications carriers performed in 2004-05. I am pleased to say that the figures show that Telstra completed 96 per cent of its connections within the time frames required by the government’s customer service guarantee and that the proportion of repairs completed on time rose one per cent to 92 per cent. Prior to the introduction of the customer service guarantee by the Howard government, people could wait up to 27 months. The time frame is now a maximum of 20 days. Optus connected 99 per cent of its CSG-eligible customers and repaired 98 per cent of faults within the required time frames. AAPT achieved 97 per cent for connections and 98 per cent for faults while Primus achieved 95 per cent for connections and 98 per cent for faults. Under Telstra’s network reliability framework, for each month in 2004-05, an average of 99.06 per cent of services had no faults. These figures are very positive for Australian consumers and demonstrate the success and importance of the tough regulated consumer safeguards that the government has imposed on telecommunications providers.

answer.para: I was asked about alternative policies. Under Labor, I think it is fair to say that no thought was given as to how to best regulate telecommunications services for consumers. Labor did not have a customer service guarantee, a network reliability framework or any priority assistance. In fact, when Labor privatised the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas, CSL and just about anything else that was not nailed down, it did so by stealth and squandered the proceeds. I am sorry to say that the ALP’s performance on telecommunications is unlikely to improve any time soon. We know from the recent well-publicised book, The Latham Diaries, that communications spokesman, Senator Conroy, told Mr Latham that he did not have any strong policy interests. Mr Latham said: ‘Stephen Conroy told me he does not have any strong policy interests and maybe he would like the communications portfolio, which I gave him. It is a frank admission. Machine men are not interested in policy, only factions and patronage.’

I can assure the Australian people that, unlike Senator Conroy and his colleagues, the Howard government are vitally interested in providing consumers with competitive telecommunications services that meet their needs. We have backed our strong policy commitments not only with words but also with a $3.1 billion package to ensure that services around the country are adequate, both now and into the future.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Ellison, Minister for Justice and Customs. Can the minister confirm that there has been a surge in the number of illegal fishing vessels spotted in Australian waters over the last year? Isn’t there evidence that these fishermen may be backed by organised crime gangs, are well organised and have adopted the tactic of building small, cheap boats that operate in groups to minimise the chance of capture? Can the minister confirm that on the Indonesian island of Roti there is a steady supply of new boats being built to replace the ones seized by Customs and the Navy and that there is no shortage of crews because of the large financial returns on offer? Can the minister indicate how many illegal fishing vessels have been sighted in Australian waters this year and, of these, how many have actually been apprehended?

—The question of illegal fishing to the north of Australia is a very important one and one which the government takes very seriously. It is true that apprehensions and legislative forfeitures of foreign fishing vessels have increased substantially over the years, particularly in the last two years. We have put resources to the north of Australia which are unprecedented. We have, for instance, a Coastwatch centre in Broome and in Darwin. We have some 33 flights regularly between Broome and Darwin and we have increased the number of sea days and aerial surveillance to the north with Navy, Air Force, Customs marine and also in relation to Coastwatch.

answer.para: In addition to that, we have set up our Joint Offshore Protection Command, which will bring together all those assets. We saw that the other day when the HMAS Geraldton was tasked to investigate an incident where the skipper of a WA fishing vessel alleged that two Indonesian fishermen tried to board his vessel. That was a matter which we investigated. They have been charged with offences under the Fisheries Act. We understand that they claimed that it was a risk of life situation and that that was the reason for their attempted boarding. But, nonetheless, we take that very seriously.

The question also raises the spectre of organised crime. We have said repeatedly in relation to the recent incursions that they have been more organised than just the traditional fishing vessels that we have seen in the past. I have asked Customs and the Australian Federal Police to look into the question of the organised syndicates or groups backing these people. We are not convinced that transnational criminal networks are involved; we think that is more applicable to the Southern Ocean. Nonetheless, we are using our resources in the region to investigate this. I opened a Customs office in Jakarta in April this year, and we are using that office and Australian Federal Police in the region working with our overseas posts to gauge the extent of the organised nature of the fishing that we are seeing, which emanates mainly from Indonesia.

When I was in Jakarta two months ago I raised this with my counterparts. They expressed a concern in relation to the increased organised fishing that Indonesia was experiencing, primarily from other countries in South-East Asia. This had, in effect, a flow-on result for us in that the organised illegal fishing coming down to Indonesia was in fact pushing their fishing further south towards Australia. We are very keen to work with the Indonesians in relation to controlling our borders and in relation to incursions. I believe that the Indonesian government is similarly concerned at the growth of organised illegal fishing.

Last week I was in East Timor and I raised it with my ministerial counterparts there. We have a joint petroleum venture area and we can go into that large section of water but not without consent from the East Timorese. We need that sort of cooperation in the region in order to effectively defeat the threat of illegal fishing.

We have said that this is a regional issue. Senator Ian Macdonald and I met with state fishing ministers just recently and we want to bring on board all the states and territories in order to conduct this fight against illegal fishing. But I can tell you that in a recent operation in the gulf we had cooperation from the Northern Territory and Queensland but not so from Western Australia. We had the Oceanic Viking, which fired shots and was instrumental in arresting four vessels. Yet Western Australia would not participate because they said it was not in their backyard. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn’t it true that no new patrol capacity will be provided as a result of the $94 million measure to supposedly counter the surge in illegal fishing that was announced in this year’s budget? Is it a fact that most of this money will be spent creating a new processing and detention facility for illegal fishermen in Darwin? Why isn’t the government increasing the number of boats on patrol in our northern waters to actually apprehend more of the illegal fishing vessels that are poaching our fish stocks?

—The $94 million goes to very good work being done by Senator Ian Macdonald in guarding our fishing stock in this country. It is an essential part of the fight against illegal fishing. It is a matter of record that in previous budgets we increased greatly our aerial surveillance and also our patrol boat hours in relation to guarding our borders. It was essential that we provide the back-up to Fisheries in order to process those illegal fishermen. This does require a whole of government approach and whole of governments approach. All we are asking is for the states and territories to join with us in that exercise, but it is a shame that in Western Australia we do not get the cooperation that we get from Queensland and the Northern Territory.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, Senator Hill. Can the minister confirm that the federal government has encouraged Australian citrus growers to vacate the domestic market and to concentrate increasingly on exporting their product? Can he also confirm that Australian citrus growers are suffering from unfair competition from imported products such that Brazilian refrigerated tankers unload fresh orange juice at Australian ports while Australian growers are unable to sell low-grade fruit for juice in Australia? Further, will the government now invoke emergency safeguard measures under the World Trade Organisation rules to increase tariffs on imported citrus products, as the United States has already done, and review Australia’s antidumping laws to address the disadvantage Australian producers face?

—The Australian government would like to see citrus growers thrive on the domestic and overseas markets. The Australian government is committed to supporting Australian rural industry to grow and to prosper. A great deal of effort has been put in by this government in opening up bilateral trade opportunities that were totally overlooked by previous governments. At the same time, this government is also endeavouring, through the multilateral round, to provide a more level playing field. So, in terms of the government’s aspiration, yes, we want citrus growers to be able to succeed domestically and on the international market and we will continue to work towards that objective. In relation to specific details concerning the citrus industry, I will refer that back to the Minister for Trade and hopefully I might get some further information in the near future.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer but, given that Biosecurity Australia yesterday announced a change of policy to permit the importation of an additional pear species from China, can the minister confirm that this was part of the negotiations to grant Australian citrus growers access to China? If so, isn’t it a breach of the WTO rules to tie market access for one product to market access for another? Doesn’t it also demonstrate the perils of negotiating a free trade agreement with China? Will the Australian government now withdraw from talks on a China-Australia free trade agreement and instead turn its attention to helping Australian growers remain viable and ensuring food security for Australia?

—With great respect, the supplementary question seemed to me to be all over the shop. Food security for Australians is not the issue at point. The issue at point is: how can we get fair access into international markets? This government has worked harder than any government of recent times in providing new and better access through bilateral agreements as well as continuing its efforts in the multilateral round. This is the only way. The honourable senator does not seem to appreciate that the Australian domestic market will always be limited. The great opportunity to expand is the potential beyond the domestic market. That is why this government is so committed to widening the opportunities—not putting up new barriers, as the honourable senator would suggest, which would simply deem that there will always be a limited and restricted opportunity for growers. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation. Is the minister aware of serious concerns in the Australian fishing industry about the impact of illegal fish poaching on our fish stocks? Hasn’t the growth of illegal fishing also led to incidents of illegal Indonesian fishing crews setting up camp on the Australian coast? Can the minister confirm the number of times this has occurred in the last 12 months? Given that the illegal fishermen also carry animals on their boats, don’t these landings represent a serious quarantine risk? Along with the major threat to our fish stocks, doesn’t the increasing number of illegal fishing boats also have the potential to undermine the security of our borders and, in addition, cause the spread of exotic diseases?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation
talker.name: Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator O’Brien for the question, which does raise some issues that are of very great concern to the Australian government. The concern we have, of course, has resulted in substantially increased assets for all of our agencies dealing with the incursion of illegal foreign fishermen, particularly, at this stage of the game, from Indonesia. I do understand—I think it was the first question Senator O’Brien asked—that the commercial fishing industry treats that with some seriousness. I have discussed this with them at length. I consider it to be very serious as well. That is why the Howard government has substantially increased its response to this threat. Back in Labor days, if anyone can remember back to those times, I think their record haul of illegal foreign fishing vessels up in the north was about 40. So far this year, we have apprehended some 135, I think, at last count. The effort that is put into it demonstrates why we are catching so many more.

answer.para: Senator O’Brien also asked about the setting up of camp on the mainland. There have been reports of that. I have to say that a lot of those reports have not been confirmed. When they are confirmed, either we get the state authorities—and, of course, it is in state areas—to go and look at it or we send Commonwealth authorities to go and look at it. Where there have been incursions, the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service immediately puts into place their plans to ensure the security of any areas that have been landed upon by foreign nationals. In the incident Senator Ellison just spoke about in Western Australia where these Indonesian fishermen boarded an Australian vessel—I think by mistake—but were later apprehended by the Australian authorities, they were not on the land when they were apprehended but there was a suggestion they had been on the land. Immediately, the Australian government authorities went in to secure that particular site and make sure there was nothing left there that could be a problem.

Senator O’Brien further asked me about animals and serious quarantine risk. I have heard about monkeys and fowls and all sorts of things, but I am not sure that those rumours have ever actually been confirmed. If there is any evidence of animals on board vessels and that land, as I say, there is a plan that would be put in place immediately to secure the area and to ensure the quarantine protocol.

Senator O’Brien further asked whether this demonstrates a problem with our border security. Quite the contrary: the amount of effort that the Howard government has put into the north is quite remarkable. Navy, Customs, Coastwatch, Fisheries, Quarantine and Immigration people do a magnificent job. We do rely on support from the fishing industry, who give us some intelligence. We also work very closely with the Indonesian government in the fight against illegal fishing. We continue to talk with Indonesian ministers, not only in the instance that Senator Ellison mentioned but during the Australian-Indonesian Ministerial Forum in Canberra where this issue was long and roundly canvassed. Senator Ian Campbell recently spoke with an Indonesian minister about the same issue. The Indonesian and Timorese ministers are visiting Australia in November to further discuss this matter with me. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I note the minister referred to the apprehension of 135 vessels. I also note that Coastwatch talked about 8,000 vessels being observed. In that context and given the threat posed by both illegal fish poaching and illegal landing from fishing vessels that is current and real, I wonder why the budget did not provide for an increase in the patrol vessel capacity in our northern waters to counter this threat? Why hasn’t the minister been able to deliver an increase, that is, additional patrol capacity, to counter the surge in illegal fishing along our northern coastline?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation
talker.name: Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: —There has been substantial increased capacity and that continues to be reviewed by the government, and we will allocate resources as the risk requires. I might use the opportunity that Senator O’Brien has afforded me to talk about this figure of 8,000 that is bandied around. This was something the state ministers were talking about because they misunderstood the information until they got a briefing. The Queensland and Northern Territory ministers now understand how this figure is calculated. It is not really that number of sightings: there are double countings, triple countings, quadruple countings; there are things right on the border; and there are boats in the MOU box. Unfortunately, the Western Australian minister still waffles in his ignorance. He was to come to two meetings that I had arranged to explain this to him, and on both occasions he did not bother to turn up. No wonder he waffles in his ignorance because he simply does not understand. When we wanted Western Australian fisheries officers to attack this problem, he refused to make them available. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Ian Macdonald—seeing as he is on a roll. Would the minister inform the Senate of how the Australian government is working on the conservation of the Murray River? Will the minister advise the Senate of any impediments to the Australian government’s efforts?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation
talker.name: Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Heffernan for that question on the Murray-Darling Basin Commission and the river basin. It is Australia’s biggest river system and our most productive river basin. Senator Heffernan, my Liberal colleague, lives slap bang in the middle of the basin. Actually, before he was in this place, he earnt his living from the basin, so he understands this matter very well. The government has taken a very strong lead in conservation work in the Murray-Darling Basin through the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. Under the constitutional set-up in Australia, of course, the states have the land management and water management rights, but through the Murray-Darling Basin Commission the Commonwealth government has been able to show a leadership role.

answer.para: In 2003, in conjunction with the relevant states, we announced the Living Murray initiative whereby we pledged to recover an average of 500 gigalitres of additional flow in the Murray to help conserve outcomes for six very important ecological sites. Mr President, you might recall that, before the last election, the Labor Party got a bit thingy about the Murray-Darling Basin. Mr Latham, their then leader, supported by all of the crowd opposite, promised to put 450 gigalitres in, whereas the government had already agreed to 500 gigalitres with the states to help with ecological sites. This was to help the Barmah-Millewa Forest, the Gunbower and Koondrook-Perricoota forests, the Hattah lakes, the Chowilla floodplain, the River Murray channel and the lower Coorong and Murray mouth system. We have now identified 240 gigalitres that will be put in the system—

talk.start.para: —It’s not enough.

—It is infinitely more than has ever been done before, and that is why this government is recognised as the greenest government ever in Australian history. We are looking for the additional 260 gigalitres needed to meet that 500 gigalitre goal. Unfortunately, the states, particularly the New South Wales government—and I have to commend Victoria; they have been much more proactive—have been very slow in identifying the additional infrastructure required to get that additional flow. Senator Brown, if you have a concern, instead of giving the Labor Party preferences in New South Wales, you might really put some pressure on the New South Wales Labor government to address that problem.

answer.para: While I am on that, during our Murray-Darling Basin Commission Ministerial Council meetings—and we just had one last Friday in Brisbane—over a period of years ministers have committed to doing certain things in the Murray-Darling Basin which will help to protect it. Ministers have gone out after those meetings and with great gusto announced the work. All the Labor ministers have been there along with the Commonwealth ministers. We get a lot of praise for the work we commit to do. A couple of years later, though, when we then have to fund the work that everyone has roundly shouted from the rooftops about, we find that the Labor state governments will not put up the money. They agree to do the work but they, particularly New South Wales, simply come and say, ‘I know we have agreed to do all of these things, but we are not going to give you the money to do them.’ I have to say that the New South Wales state government is a serial offender in that. It is aided, supported and abetted by the Victorian government, but I think only out of solidarity to the Labor movement. The Victorian government is much better at it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I ask the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Coonan, whether she recalls her comments to the National Press Club in August:

quote.para: ... I am looking at media ownership and foreign investment reform in conjunction with the broader policy questions relating to digital technology ... platforms. This is just common sense.

question.para: Does the minister recall also telling the Press Club that it is essential that we look at a broader framework than containing it simply to cross and foreign? Is the minister aware of reports last week that the Prime Minister has abandoned digital television reforms that would increase choice for consumers because of opposition from media proprietors? Can the minister confirm that she has been overruled by the Prime Minister, and will the minister now admit that the government’s media policy is driven by the interests of the media barons, not the interests of consumers?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts
talker.name: Senator COONAN

talk.start.para: —No, I am certainly not aware of the comments attributed to the Prime Minister by Senator Conroy. The situation is that the government has had a very longstanding policy to implement media ownership reforms, which includes the relaxation of the foreign ownership restrictions and the relaxation of the cross-media reforms whilst maintaining the specific media concentration rules and with a view to protecting diversity. So the current position is that there are under consideration a number of responses to digital reviews that have been mandated in the legislation. Included in those digital reviews are a number of matters which are self-executing in any event, such as some relaxations that will happen quite irrespective of whether or not the government makes another decision, because they are mandated to occur within the legislation.

answer.para: The government has committed to reforming media ownership laws because they are outmoded, and even Senator Conroy would appreciate, although he has not a strong interest in communications or in media—he has admitted that; it has been well documented in Mr Latham’s diaries that he has not much interest in communications—that there are a number of other platforms now available and a plethora of ways in which people can now get news and views over a number of other platforms besides the regulated platforms that the government has under consideration as part of the reforms that it has on tap.

What is happening, as is well known, is well documented and was referred to at great length in my address to the Press Club, is that we are currently consulting with all stakeholders—certainly not just those who run media businesses but all stakeholders—including people such as rights owners and all of those who have an interest and a stake in ensuring that the government puts in place a framework that will be responsive to the new and emerging media environment. So I am continuing to consult with stakeholders, obviously with the authority of the government to do so, as a means of achieving these goals to ensure that we can place media companies in a position to take advantage of all of the new platforms and all of the new technologies whilst at the same time protecting diversity, because the end game is that consumers must have the benefit of these reforms together with the industry.

Senator Conroy is quite wrong to imply that any decisions have been made about any of these matters. He is quite wrong to impute to the Prime Minister any particular ruling out of any of these proposals. We will continue to put in place a framework that will be responsive and will deliver, as we do with all of our policy positions, for the benefit of all Australians.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister whether she recalls her comments to the Australian on digital television in August when she stated:

quote.para: I’m not interested in shutting down new and interesting ways to do things ... I’m going to make sure that the free-to-air (networks), as well as the other providers, have an opportunity to take advantage of all of these new ways of doing things and getting viewers.

question.para: Can the minister advise the Senate whether these views are shared by the Prime Minister?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts
talker.name: Senator COONAN

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Conroy for a supplementary that was a bit of a non sequitur. Every single time that Senator Conroy opens his mouth on these issues he proves that he knows less and less about this portfolio that he is supposed to be getting across. His ill-founded response to my comments on media shows that he has absolutely no idea about diversity, he has no idea about what the mandated positions are that are going to happen in any event and he does not even know how many media proprietors there are in both the Victorian and the Sydney markets. He has even got that wrong. It is time that Senator Conroy goes back, gets across his portfolio and then asks some questions based on some facts instead of supposition.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Are there any motions to take note of answers? I call Senator O’Brien.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS
debateinfo.type: Questions Without Notice: Take Note of Answers

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Justice and Customs (Senator Ellison) and the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation (Senator Ian Macdonald) to questions without notice asked by Senators Sterle and O’Brien today relating to illegal fishers.

talk.start.para: —This is the subject of an MPI.
—I welcome the interjection from Senator Ferguson because, yes, we do propose to further discuss this matter today, but the reality is that we could not—
—I am sorry to interrupt; I call Senator Lyn Allison.

—Pursuant to standing order 74(5) I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing for an explanation as to why answers have not been provided to questions on notice No. 907 and No. 908, which were asked on 11 May this year.
—Senator Allison, you did miss the call, but I am prepared to take your point and then we will resume debate on the motion to take note of answers.

—I would point out that I was standing right at the point when Senator Hill stood. There has been an issue with the crossbench not being recognised in seeking your attention—on numerous occasions, if I may say so.

—I would just point out to you that I was not in the chair when the motion to take note of answers commenced. That had commenced before I assumed the chair. If the record notes that then I am quite happy. I do not think the appropriate minister is here, Senator Allison.
—I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the minister’s failure to provide either an answer or an explanation.

speech.para: I point out that my office contacted the office of the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing and indicated that I would request an answer from the minister today. So this is disappointing. Maybe it is because of the mix-up and not being recognised at this end of the chamber. I do not know. Maybe that was an opportunity to sneak out, as it were.

I do ask that the Senate note that these questions were asked back in May, so they are now four months overdue. I will just go through them. I asked the minister to confirm that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee report of the Working Party on the Registration of Drugs for Use in Children was completed way back in 1997 for the Therapeutic Goods Administration and to provide an outline of the recommendations made by that working party, what action had been planned and what action had been taken to implement the recommendations of that working party, whether the working party had been discontinued—as I suspect it has—and, if so, what follow-up studies had been established. We are talking about drugs for children, and I would have thought there would be some urgency in responding to such questions—unless, of course, this is so embarrassing that the government is not able to do so.

I also asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing whether the government had undertaken any investigations into the factors that have contributed to the increase in government rebates for IVF services over the past 10 years and, if so, whether a copy could be provided of any information or report resulting from investigations; what groups, if any, were consulted prior to May 2005 regarding possible restrictions on access to Medicare rebates for IVF procedures; what data the government had on the proportion of Australian women accessing IVF services; changes in the proportion over the past 10 years; and the range and average number of IVF cycles undertaken by a fertile woman. I also asked for information to be provided on the average out-of-pocket costs for women on a single cycle of IVF over the past 10 years. I asked that question at a time when this debate was under way in the community. It was my view that we could not have a proper debate unless that information had been provided. It is four months on and it is still not here and the minister is not in this place to explain why it is that that information has not been provided.

I think it is the case that I have about 11 questions that have not been answered and that are similarly long outstanding. I could probably stand here for the rest of the afternoon going through them but I would expect the same situation to apply—that is, the minister is not here or available to explain why it is that answers have not been provided. I notice that Minister Hill is still in the chamber. On a number of occasions I have made a request with respect to his answer to my question No. 29, which was put on notice on 16 November last year and still remains unanswered by Senator Hill. I think it is appalling that the government shows so little interest and so little regard for questions that are properly put.

talk.start.para: —What is the question?

—Minister, presumably, you have asked me about your question. I asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate: when will the minister respond to my letter of 7 April concerning orders for the production of documents? Here again we have seen a government very dismissive about requests for the production of documents in this place—returns to order. I in fact wrote to you, Senator Hill, in November last year saying that there was an interpretation of the government’s responsibility with regard to this that was all over the place like a dog’s dinner, if I can use that term; that is, some ministers were saying—
—What documents? What subject matter?

—Documents generally, Senator Hill. It is about the excuses that are provided by ministers in this place for not providing documents. There is no consistency with those excuses. There is no rhyme or reason why half of them are even used or constitute reasonable reasons for not allowing the Senate to have those documents. I put this to you in a very well-considered letter and asked you to respond. It is now almost a year and I still do not have any answer from you. Senator Hill, you are as bad as anybody else, as far as I can see, in being so dismissive of the Senate and its right, I would argue, to access information and documents as necessary.

speech.para: It is a disappointment that the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing is not here. No doubt she will say she did not get notice from my office. I will check again. It is usually the case that the notice was indeed provided to the office. Nonetheless, it seems to me that, even if notice were not given, ministers should hang about to make sure that there is not something that senators wish to ask.
Question agreed to.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS
debateinfo.type: Questions Without Notice: Take Note of Answers

talk.start.para: —I moved earlier to take note of answers given in question time today to opposition questions regarding illegal fishing in Australia’s northern waters.
—You are in order, Senator O’Brien.

—Thank you. I noted an interjection earlier about this being a matter for the MPI today. The reason that we are taking note is the incredible answers provided by Ministers Ellison and Ian Macdonald today. Frankly, the thrust of the questions was to point out the dramatic increase in illegal fishing in Australia’s northern waters and the paucity of the government response as to why additional resources in the form of additional vessels had not been applied to dealing with the problem.

speech.para: We had a question from Senator Sterle about organised crime being involved, and Minister Ellison acceded to the proposition that organised crime is believed to be involved. We had Senator Sterle talking about small, inexpensive vessels constructed on the Indonesian island of Roti being used because, if they were captured, they could easily be replaced. I understand that Minister Ellison acceded to that proposition. We had Minister Ian Macdonald acceding—reluctantly nevertheless—to the proposition that illegal fishermen were supposed to be setting up camp on the Australian coastline and that there was intelligence that suggested they were bringing animals onto the coastline that would create a quarantine risk for this country. Minister Macdonald tried to explain that away by saying, ‘After the event, we send some crews in where we know there has been an incursion and we try and deal with the problem.’ The fact of the matter is that there are thousands of incursions, and Minister Macdonald suggesting that 135 interceptions and apprehensions is a good statistic in the light of thousands of incursions is, frankly, an admission that the government is incapable of dealing with this new threat.

Minister Macdonald suggested that, although Coastwatch had observed more than 8,000 vessels, there was double or triple counting and the number was not anywhere near 8,000. He did not say, of course, that Coastwatch do not look at every area every day, so what they observe is not necessarily the actual number of incursions that is taking place. If you reduce the 8,000 by a factor of two or three and then multiply it by the number of days and areas that they are not involved in, you are probably back to a figure of around 8,000, if not more, incursions into Australian waters. That is over 20 incursions a day into Australian waters, with pillaging of Australian fishing stocks.

The intelligence is that the shark fishery in Indonesian waters is such that the stock is in danger and the fishermen are now coming into Australian waters to take shark because shark fin is so valuable in South-East Asian markets. The government have no response to that. The government say that they are building a detention centre in Darwin and they are finding a place to incarcerate fishermen that are captured, but they are only capturing a small number of fishermen, and the modus operandi of the fishermen has changed so that they are in smaller groups and in smaller vessels spread across the fishery, perhaps with mother ships outside Australian waters. The government have no response to this way of predating upon the Australian fishing stocks.

Is it any wonder, as is conceded by Minister Macdonald, that the Australian fishing industry is alarmed that we have no response to illegal fishermen predating upon and endangering the fishing stock in Australian waters, endangering the livelihood of Australian fishermen and at the same time introducing risk to the Australian coastline and threatening to board Australian vessels? The situation shows that the government has failed to protect Australia’s oceans and failed to protect Australia’s borders and it brings the government’s claim of being strong on border protection into stark relief as being, in this area, an abject failure. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise with some amazement in this debate on the motion to take note of answers on illegal fishing. I understood when I came to this place that the idea is that the opposition pick on something that the government is weak in. I am absolutely amazed that they have decided to push an attack once again on our wondrous and probably without peer border protection. It is seen that way around the world. The globe continually looks to Australia for leadership in this area. I am miffed that we could not find something else to talk about today.

speech.para: I am very proud to be part of a government that has a record of dealing with some of the most sophisticated threats to our northern fishery. It is not that we are always dealing with 200-metre vessels that have the most sophisticated GPS. The sophistication of the challenge is that we are dealing with every single type of demographic. We have everything from very small canoes to quite large ex-Taiwanese gill netters operating in the area.

It is surprising that those on the other side of the chamber do not have an understanding of this. I understand that being in opposition must be a bit difficult in getting information, but I think the internet and a few calls around the place would help you understand that the basis of this situation is that the income of the average Indonesian fisherman working around some of these places is $480 a year. With the average shark fetching between $200 and $600 a kilo, you can actually make $2,000 for every shark you catch. Obviously this is not an issue that is necessarily going to go away, but still, in facing that sophisticated challenge and that huge economic push that continues to be there, this government, in contrast with those on the other side of the chamber, has sent out a very clear and hard message.

The opposition give me a bit of humour with my fishing mates over a very small glass of wine at night. The opposition talk about their coastguard. The immediate answer to this problem, according to those on the other side, is a can of paint and a cupboard of new uniforms. ‘We have got the coastguard—no worries about that! We are simply going to paint the boats blue, put a red stripe on them and run out a new uniform.’ Let me tell you, Mr Deputy President, that that unsophisticated and clumsy approach to a very sophisticated challenge is not going to be seen by anyone as making any contribution to this debate at all.

It went to the ridiculous when they had people like Bob McClelland going to America—it was pre-election, so they were all pretty much in this Lathamesque moment—people who one moment were attacking the United States foreign policy like some benzedrine puff adder and who the next moment were saying: ‘While you’re over there, Bob, have a bit of a look at their Coastwatch policy. We’ll have a look at that. We might even be able to borrow it.’ Borrow it? They took it holus bolus. It included, of course, the wonderful idea of people hanging out of helicopters shooting at boats with rifles. If that is the level of sophistication, I really think they should have picked on another issue.

We have put a very serious stamp of compliance across this very wide and difficult arena. We already have 15 craft working in that area. Both Customs and the Royal Australian Navy work literally thousands of sea days every year. I take this opportunity to defend their reputation—the huge efforts that these men and women put in in sometimes the most difficult of conditions. They are simply to be commended and not to be criticised. They do an absolutely excellent job. In testament to the effort they make, there have been 1,261 administrative seizures in the last five years, and they burnt and destroyed 555 vessels. The other side talked about the wonderful industry on Roti Island. Let me tell you as a fact that Roti’s capacity in boatbuilding in 1997 was six vessels a year. That information arrived on my desk five minutes ago. That huge industrial capacity is not going to replace 555 boats in anyone’s language and anyone’s time. This cuts at the core of the capacity of those people who wish to come to our waters to steal and do damage.

There have also been some accusations from the other side about sightings. A lot of those sightings come through me. People ring me, and they are disturbed about these sorts of things and about some of these sightings. The stories about bringing animals to the Australian mainland are a complete furphy. The Australian government are very proud of an excellent compliance regime that has slowed down Indonesian fishermen. It continues to send them a clear message that, if they come to Australia with the intent of stealing fish, they will be stopped. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to take note of answers given today by the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation and the Minister for Justice and Customs to questions asked about the repeated incursions by foreign fishermen into Australian waters. What an unconvincing performance it was. The drivel the honourable ministers gave for answers to the serious questions the opposition asked about Australia’s border security is typical of the arrogance of this out-of-touch government. But we should not be surprised by the ministers’ answers to questions on this important issue. The neglect of border security is a whole-of-government approach for the Howard government, from the Prime Minister down.

speech.para: Jon Ford, the Western Australian Minister for Fisheries, is doing his best to care for the fragile marine ecology of Western Australian waters by creating sanctuary zones in marine parks and adjusting bag limits, only to be undermined by the Howard government’s inability to keep looting foreign fishermen out of Western Australian waters. Minister Ford has been calling on the Howard government to account for its failure to respond to the massive numbers of illegal fishing vessels that are pillaging Western Australian waters. But the Howard government do not like the success he has been having in drawing public attention to their failures.
Senator Macdonald, the Commonwealth minister for fisheries, gave the game away the other day when he said:

quote.para: The WA Government needs to take a dose of reality and if there are problems in WA waters then they should be policing them …

speech.para: If the honourable minister knew anything about his portfolio, he would know that ‘WA waters’ are a thin band around the coast of Western Australia. And what are they surrounded by? What surrounds WA waters? Commonwealth waters! What a clown—what an absolute clown. Someone get a stretcher, the minister has shot himself in the foot. How do these boats appear in Western Australian waters? Do they teleport there? Do they get there by osmosis? No. The only reason there would ever be a problem in WA waters would be if the Howard government had failed in its responsibility to police Commonwealth waters.

What is the attitude of the honourable senator to this admission of failure? He wants the Western Australian government to take a dose of reality. The reality is that this government talks big about border protection but, when it is put to the test, it fails. You can imagine the Prime Minister at election time, up on the podium, his bottom lip sticking out as he says, ‘We will decide who fishes in Australian waters and the circumstances in which they fish.’ If you listen to this government at election time they will have you believe that they actually care about border security. But, once the election is over, it is a completely different story—a story of buck passing and neglect.

Just the other day the Prime Minister was asked on talkback radio whether he thought the government was doing its job properly when it came to protecting Australian waters from illegal fishing vessels. What was the Prime Minister’s answer? He said, ‘What you’re seeing at the moment is the system working.’ He then went on to boast that authorities were on track to catch 180 illegal fishing boats throughout Australian waters this year. Bravo! I wonder if the Prime Minister is aware that Coastwatch aircraft spotted more than 8,000 vessels in the last financial year alone—and the Prime Minister hopes to catch 180 of them! Is this the Prime Minister’s idea of a system that is working?

As I said earlier, the neglect of border security is a whole-of-government approach for the Howard government. Minister Ellison put in a shocker of a performance the other day. He said that the government was being proactive in its response to illegal fishers and rejected the Western Australian government’s assertions that more resources were needed to ensure the security of both the Western Australian border and fish stocks. That is because Minister Ellison has a cunning plan. Minister Ellison does not believe more resources are needed; he believes fewer resources are needed. That is why, instead of standing up for Western Australia’s interests, he is standing up to protect the Howard government’s decision to remove, as of March next year, $1.2 million a year in funding for the internal operations unit based in Western Australia.

The internal operations unit’s purpose is to combat illegal fishing incursions by foreign vessels. Apparently, WA does not need it anymore. Is this another example of what the Prime Minister means when he says that the system is working? Minister Ellison likes to boast about what he likes to call ‘the unprecedented resources’ the Howard government is devoting to protecting Australian waters. He loves to tell people about the 33 flights a week between Broome and Darwin. Can you imagine the flights? The pilot is looking out of the window and saying: ‘There’s one. There’s one. Look, there’s another one.’ Eight thousand a year and the Prime Minister hopes to catch 180. The Howard government’s system is allowing droves of Indonesian fishermen who could be exposed to tuberculosis, carrying hens exposed to the avian flu and being kept company by dogs that could be exposed to rabies— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Why are none of us on this side of the chamber surprised that at question time and during the debate to take note the Labor Party would come in here to try to get some political mileage—some cheap political point scoring—out of illegal fishing? It is a very serious issue, and yet we have just heard the last opposition senator make frivolous, humorous remarks.

speech.para: Let me tell you how seriously Labor take this. WA announced just recently that they were going to close a fishing patrol unit because the Commonwealth was not funding them to the tune of $1.2 million. Let us get that in some sort of context. This is how much Labor really cares about it. Guess how much the surplus budget will deliver to this state Labor government this year: $1.3 billion. And for the price of $1.2 million, they allege, they are going to close their fishing patrol unit. That is how much they care. They care not a jot for fishing. All they care about is coming in here and trying to snatch a cheap vote with a very crass, weak, pathetic argument about fishing in an environment where Australia has never had so much surveillance or so much expenditure.

We are replacing 15 Fremantle class patrol boats with 14 Armidale class patrol boats. We have more Customs patrol boats and more AFFA fishing control boats in this region than ever before. Let me tell you: it has taken us 10 years to pick up the pieces from the Hawke-Keating shemozzle. They never spent a cent on protecting Australia’s borders. We had to go out there and handle all of the illegal immigration and all of the illegal fishing; we had to upgrade security; defence had to be upgraded—we have spent billions of dollars repairing the damage of Labor because of their profligate neglect of security and border protection. Do not come in here with your hollow, cheap, point-scoring attack when state Labor in Western Australia is dropping its fishing patrol unit for the want of, allegedly, $1.2 million in the face of its $1.3 billion surplus. What hollow, crocodile tears! When will you learn? The Australian public are never going to be sucked in by such cheap political chicanery.

talk.start.para: —You couldn’t even go for five minutes!

—Does that mean I get to go for seven minutes? I do not? What a pity! You see, we have Senator Johnston smirking and not even serious about his contribution to this debate. There is no genuine offer, trying to validate the government’s position. He cannot even defend the government for five minutes. The illegal fishing debacle in our northern waters is an absolute sham. It has long been a problem. Senator Johnston would want us to believe that it goes all the way back to the Hawke and Keating days. Well, you have been in government for nine long years now, Senator Johnston, and it is about time the federal government actually did something about the illegal fishing problem in our northern waters and the depletion of fish stocks that is occurring.

speech.para: It is a growing problem and it clearly needs far more attention and resources than this current government is prepared to give it. An article in the Australian on 6 September said:

quote.para: SIGHTINGS of foreign fishing boats in Australian waters ... have leapt 50 per cent over two years—and most of them are there illegally.

A briefing paper by the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, obtained under Freedom of Information laws, shows sightings ... average 22 a day and that a total of 8108 were spotted last financial year.

speech.para: That is the number my colleague mentioned. Of course, most of them cannot be apprehended as either they are too close to the border or there are simply no Australian vessels near enough to catch them. You can have planes fly over as often as you like and blue dots can be placed on a map by a computer as often as you like but, unless you actually have enough boats in the area and enough people in the area to do something about these vessels, the plan will not work. Furthermore, the Australian said that Customs told them there has been a 60 per cent increase in the number of foreign boats apprehended by Customs and Navy in the past 12 months. No-one is doubting the enormous effort that is put in by Customs officials and by our defence people, but clearly the government has to realise that the effort is not enough, that their plan is not working and that there needs to be much more attention given to this problem.

Not only have the number of boats gone up but the boats are coming closer. For example, in the Northern Territory they come right down into the Gulf of Carpentaria waters, down and around Groote Eylandt, and they have been seen close in and around the Wessel Islands, not far north of Nhulunbuy. Local northern fishery boats regularly see and report on foreign boats. In fact, we have had some up the creek at Maningrida. On 18 April on ABC radio Mr Gary Ward, the chair of the Gulf Fishermen’s Association, said:

quote.para: ... there’s God knows how many boats out there and it’s just open slather ... the Gulf is just full of them.

speech.para: And the boats are getting bigger and more sophisticated. They are carrying GPS and navigation equipment. There can be absolutely no doubt that they know just where they are. They have freezer facilities so they can catch and carry far bigger amounts of fish. In an interview on the ABC radio morning program on 17 August, Ian Smith, the CEO of the Northern Territory Seafood Council said, ‘We’ll continue our lobbying, trying to send wake-up calls, saying, “Look, we have a problem and it’s been ongoing.”’ He went on to say: ‘I mean, it’s not getting any better. In fact, it’s probably getting worse.’

We have the amateur fishing association continually ringing my office and complaining, and rightfully so, that this government is not doing enough to stop this problem. The issue that has been raised by my colleagues about quarantine is a fact. Senator Scullion, one of the boats in the harbour that your company looks after was known to have a dog on it in recent months, and an answer to a question on notice that I received from this government signalled that that was a problem.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The senator just said that there were boats in Darwin Harbour being looked after by my company. She knows full well that is not the case. I have absolutely no association with Barefoot Marine, and for three years in this place committees of this chamber discussed that and found unequivocally that that was not the case. I think she should withdraw that remark.
—It really is not a point of order; it is a debating point, but your point has been noted.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice and Customs (Senator Ellison) to a question without notice asked by Senator Stott Despoja today relating to the Privacy Act.

speech.para: My question related to section 7C of the Privacy Act, which exempts political acts and practices from privacy laws. It is something I have commented on on numerous occasions, and I have moved amendments in this place to prevent politicians—that is, all of us—enjoying this wide ranging exemption under the Privacy Act. The Privacy Act in 2000 was extended to include the private sector, but it did not extend to politicians. I think the time has come for this government to seriously consider, if not immediately amend, the Privacy Act to, as a minimum, remove the exemption for politicians but also perhaps more broadly strengthen the provisions relating to medical and sensitive information—in particular, medical records. I have talked often as well about the need for privacy protection of genetic information, and I will continue to bang on about that issue for as long as it takes for us to get protection of privacy information in this place.

A couple of issues have come to the attention of members of this place and the public in recent times. One of them was through the Democrat initiated Senate inquiry into privacy laws in this country, where we heard evidence from a number of individuals and organisations like the Privacy Foundation, the Australian Medical Association, the privacy commissioner for Victoria and others that demonstrated that the political exemption was wide ranging, out of date and inappropriate and had never been seriously justified. We heard of one case where the jurisdiction of the federal Privacy Commissioner did not extend to phone calls, which some honourable members would recall, made during the last election campaign in the voices of, I believe, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, Peter Costello, to silent numbers held by electors. Those people did not disclose that information, nor did they seek to come home and hear a cutesy election message on their answering machine. The problem is that it cannot be investigated and it is not within the jurisdiction of the Privacy Commissioner. Why? Because of these wide ranging exemptions that we politicians enjoy but other businesses, industry, individuals and public sector organisations et cetera do not enjoy. It is time to change that.

More alarmingly, in the Senate today I referred to a case that is ongoing and has received widespread coverage. That is the allegation that Senator McGauran was responsible for obtaining and disclosing the medical records of a woman who had undergone a late-term abortion. We certainly read about it in a piece written by Meagan Shaw in the Age newspaper, which reported that the name of the woman was sent to them in the information provided to them by Senator McGauran. I am not saying that; that was written in the piece. Regardless of what you feel about the information being obtained without consent or being disclosed, there has to be a bigger debate in this place about whether or not, when the act refers to political acts and political practices, we are really talking about medical records. Is it really the case that the act intends that they not be under the jurisdiction of the Privacy Commissioner?

There are other issues beyond the allegations against Senator McGauran. There is a dispute that involves the Royal Women’s Hospital and the Medical Practitioners Board. In that case, the Melbourne Magistrate’s Court ordered that the woman’s health and medical information be disclosed to the Medical Practitioners Board despite the patient’s refusal, despite the patient’s lack of consent. I use that case to illustrate one thing and one thing only: that we should get rid of this ridiculous exemption that we have under law that businesses and public sector and other organisations are not subject to. I will be introducing a private member’s bill to make sure this happens if the government does not beat me to it, and I invite them to do so. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

The petition of the undersigned shows that citizens are deeply concerned about the proposal to establish an immigration detention centre at the Shaftesbury Campus.

Whereas the 1998 Synod of the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne carried without dissent the following motion:

“That this Synod regrets the Government’s adoption of procedures for certain people seeking political asylum in Australia which exclude them from all public income support while withholding permission to work, thereby creating a group of beggars dependent on the Churches and charities for food and the necessities of life;

and calls upon the Federal government to review such procedures immediately and remove all practices which are manifestly inhumane and in some cases in contravention of our national obligations as a signatory of the UN Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.”
We, therefore, the individual, undersigned attendees at St Simon’s Catholic Church, Rowville, VIC 3178 petition the Senate in support of the above mentioned motion.
AND we, as in duty bound will ever pray.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Siewert to move on the next day of sitting:

item.para: That the Senate—

item.label: (a)

item.label: (i)
item.para: the mouth of the Murray River in South Australia is in terminal decline and risks permanent collapse unless more water is provided for the river,

item.label: (ii)
item.para: scientific studies and surveys of the internationally‑protected area show that:

item.label: (a)
item.para: the Coorong was Australia’s largest permanent breeding colony for pelicans, however pelicans have not bred for almost 4 years,

item.label: (b)

item.label: (c)
item.para: salinity levels are three times that of sea water,

item.label: (d)
item.para: 12 species of fish are locally extinct, and

item.label: (e)
item.para: numbers of migratory wader birds have dropped from 150 000 in the 1980s to 50 000 now, while numbers of the curlew sandpiper have dropped from 40 000 to 2 000,

item.label: (iii)

item.label: (iv)

item.label: (b)
item.para: recognises that the quickest and most cost-effective way of meeting environmental flow targets is to purchase water on the open market; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: calls on the Government to:

item.label: (i)
item.para: support the purchase of water on the open market, and

item.label: (ii)
item.para: address this national emergency.
